content:
## Recent space activity

## Space contributors

We have a python script that generates manifest file according to output files and copy all files to related sftp folder. This script will the last part of the export mechanism. For now, we can fallow steps below to share our output files with ASO:

(All of steps should be done in App-Server)

1. Delete all files in E:\ExportOperations\output folder if there are any.
2. Copy Result files to E:\ExportOperations\output folder.
3. Run ExportOutputFiles.py script in E:\ExportOperations folder using cmd (or powershell)

This script has 2 arguments :

- output type ("final", "prelim1" or "prelim2") -must
- environment ("prod") -optional, default "dev"

examples commands:

```bash
> python ExportOutputFiles.py "final"
```

```bash
> python ExportOutputFiles.py "prelim1" "prod"
```

python ExportOutputFiles.py "final"
```

```bash
> python ExportOutputFiles.py "prelim1" "prod"
```

> Warning: When you need to run the command manually, the way code reach the sftp folder changes because the user permissions.Therefore, you need to comment-out the last line in the picture below in the file E:\ExportOperations\sftp.py in the app server.

Screenshots to open Powershell and run command:

When above command is done, files (including manifest) are copied to the designated folder.

> Info: After files are copied, a zip containing all sent files will be created in E:\ExportOperations\backup folder. We may build a cleanup process that deletes old zips in the future.

\ExportOperations\backup folder. We may build a cleanup process that deletes old zips in the future.

> Warning: For the test period we fill all output folders at the same time (final, prelim1, prelim2). However, this will not be the case when we go live. So, Do not run separate commands for each folder! Otherwise, new manifest files will be generated every time.Recommended way:Run command for the FinalFolder by passing argument "final".Then, Copy resulting files from FinalFolder to Prelim1Folder and Prelim2Folder manually.

> Warning: Academy's IT Team is responsible for deleting all files in the sftp folders after they get them. However, they have not implemented this process yet.So, Make sure that target folder is empty before run the command. Otherwise, all files are overwritten except manifest file because each manifest file has unique name.In the next week, we will add a control script that checks if target folder is empty. If not empty, a warning mail will be sent.

#

# File Structure

### File tree

```
invent-academy-datastore|-- hive|-- parquet|-- bootstrap|-- lib|-- archive| |-- cache|-- model-data| |-- daily-data| |-- weekly-data| |-- forecast-pairs| +-- seasonality-multipliers|-- output| |-- forecast| | |-- ma-with-seasonality| | | |-- latest| | | |-- 2018-10-19T16:22:29Z| | | +-- 2018-10-18T16:21:30Z| | |-- prophet| | |-- xgb| | |-- smart-selection| | +-- some-other-awesome-model| |-- lostsales| |-- target| +-- outlier+-- jupyter

### Bucket Details

s3://invent-*customername*-datastore/

s| |-- target| +-- outlier+-- jupyter

### Bucket Details

s3://invent-*customername*-datastore/

| Key | Explanation | Lifecycle Policy |
| --- | --- | --- |
| hive/ | Hive tables. Raw data | no glacier no delete |
| archive/ | For debuging/caching purposes only | glacier after 30 days delete after 360 days |
| parquet/ | Parquet files. Raw data | no glacier no delete |
| bootstrap/ | Anything related to cluster initialization | no glacier no delete |
| lib/ | EMR step scripts. Python/R/SQL/Shell | no glacier no delete |
| model-data/ | Processed parquet files to use in algorithms directly | no glacier no delete |
| output/ | Model results | no glacier no delete |
| jupyter/ | Jupyter related files/notebooks | no glacier no delete |

NOOB platformunun RPL sistemi içerisine dahil edilmesi ile birlikte, eski ve yeni RPL akışı ile ilgili bir takım net olmayan noktaları açığa kavuşturmak adına bu sayfa oluşturulmuştur. Yukarıdaki akışa göre; koyu sarı renk ile belirtilmiş alan mevcutta ASO'da çalışan akışı gösterirken turkuaz ile belirtilmiş platformlar ideal akışı / toolları göstermektedir. Akış ile ilgili kabaca  ve  ile konuştuk; üzerine eğilmemiz gereken öncelikli konu olarak yeni düzende hangi manipulative tabloların NOOB ile entegre edilmesi gerektiğini çıkarmak oldu. Buna göre, RPL sistemi içerisinde, bu tabloların akışa dahil olduğu bölgeleri 4'e ayırdık;

1) 4cast öncesi satış datası üzerindeki manipuleler,

2) Raw 4cast değerinin manipule edilmesi,

3) Raw Target değerinin manipule edilmesi,

4) Raw SOQ değerinin manipule edilmesi.

ipule edilmesi,

3) Raw Target değerinin manipule edilmesi,

4) Raw SOQ değerinin manipule edilmesi.

Çıkartabildiğim input tabloların bu bölgelere dağılımını aşağıda bulabilirsiniz; atladığım tablolar olabilir gözünüze çarpan olursa lütfen editlemeleriniz yapın. Tablolardan bazıları GNC tarafında kullanılan tablolar, MAPS tarafında eşleniği olmayan tablo bulunması ihtimaline karşılık onları da aşağıda göreceksiniz. En altta linkini paylaştığım gsheet'te ise MAPS Unified'da bulunan tüm tabloların listesi bulunuyor. SchemaCode değeri 8 olanlar forecast şemalı olanlar, 13 olanlar ise replenishment şemalılar.

Open Issues:

Yeni akışla ilgili sorularımızı aşağıda listeliyorum; siz de sorularınızı aşağıya yazabilirsiniz.

:

Yeni akışla ilgili sorularımızı aşağıda listeliyorum; siz de sorularınızı aşağıya yazabilirsiniz.

1. Effective Target hesaplanan kısmın ideal düzende MAPS taradında mı yoksa NOOB'da mı handle edileceği ile ilgili bir soru işareti var. MAPS tarafının bu noktada güçlü olmasından dolayı, NOOB'da ERT hesaplamak istesek bile yakın vadede bu değişimi yapmak zor gibi gözüküyor. İleride bu kısmı da MAPS'ten çıkartmak istiyor muyuz?
2. Analizler için algoritma ekibi veya müşteri isteği üzerine CE tarafı geçmişe yönelik Forecast run sonuçlarını kullanarak test runları alabiliyor. NOOB yapısında bu runlar nasıl alınabilecek?
3. Internal ve external raporların hangi platformdaki datadan besleneceği ile ilgili bir akışımız bulunmakta mıdır? Örneğin ROP değerlerinin historical kayıtlarını NOOB'da tutup SOQ kayıtlarını MAPS'te mi tutucaz? Bu durumda birden fazla kaynağa mı raporları bağlamak gerekecek?

, , , Kübra Özlem Erzincanlı, ,  bilgilerinize.

## Scheduling

|  | Early Data Extraction | Final Data Extraction |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Monday - Saturday | 18.00 | 21.00 |
| Sunday | 17.00 | 20.00 |

Scheduling may differ in time. ASO may change extraction times according to their maintenance programs etc.

We requested ASO IT Team that at least three hours gap between early and final data extraction times. Whenever a change in extraction schedules occurs, we expect that the gap will remain as three hours.

## Staging and Maps Databases

There are three different connections:

p will remain as three hours.

## Staging and Maps Databases

There are three different connections:

|  |  |  |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | US-DB-02 | Includes production and test databases for staging (AcademyStaging and AcademyStagingTest respectively). Also includes configuration databases for data transfer from CSV to staging. |
| 2 | US-RDS-04 | Includes production Maps main and reporting databases (Academy and AcademyReporting respectively) |
| 3 | US-RDS-04-Test | Includes test Maps main and reporting databases (Academy and AcademyReporting respectively). RDS may change according to restore options |

For most recent connection information, please check [Cloud Setup].

There are linked servers in order to connect databases and transfer data. e.g. You can reach production database from US-DB-02 via [US-RDS-04] prefix. To find server connection keywords, please check Server Objects > Linked Servers under database connection that you have.

tion keywords, please check Server Objects > Linked Servers under database connection that you have.

## Stock Date & Replenishment Target Date

In inventory related tables, there isn't any date information. We need to make an assumption with the other information we have. The timestamp in the data feed folder name is used to make the date assumption. Since data extraction is scheduled at 9 pm for final data transfer, we consider that extraction may last longer and finish after 12 pm. In order to cover this situation, we subtract five hours from the timestamp and take the resulting date as the *Stock Date* for the current data transfer. (SSIS_Config.dbo.GetLastStockDate())

For *Replenishment Target Date*, we add one day to *Stock Date.*

|  | Steps for Early Data Transfer | Corresponding SQL Server Agent Jobs |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Wait for data feed and check manifest file | Academy Data Transfer - CHECK Early |
| 2 | Data transfer from CSV files into Staging tables in temp schema. | Academy Data Transfer - CSV Early |
| 3 | Data transfer from Staging tables into Maps tables | Academy Data Transfer - MAPS Early |
| 4 | Update replenishment.ExternalReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels table using AcademyReporting.dbo.ReorderPointsTempTable that is refreshed daily. | Academy Data Transfer - MAPS Early |
| 5 | Update warehouse.ExternalReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels table using AcademyReporting.dbo.DC_RPL_TargetTempTable is refreshed daily. (1) | Academy Data Transfer - MAPS Early |

yReporting.dbo.DC_RPL_TargetTempTable is refreshed daily. (1) | Academy Data Transfer - MAPS Early |
| 6 | Update following run parameters:"ReplenishmentTargetDate" in the "Prelim1Run" preset for RPL"ReplenishmentTargetDate" in the "Prelim1WRPLRun" preset for WRPL"ResultTransferTargetDate" in the "Prelim1Run" preset for RTby using stock date generated from data feed folder timestamp. ReplenishmentTargetDate = StockDate + 1 | Academy Data Transfer - MAPS Early |
| 7 | Write the following records into engine.AlgoRuns table:RPL with preset Prelim1RunWRPL with preset Prelim1WRPLRun RT with preset Prelim1Run | Academy Data Transfer - MAPS Early |
| 8 | After RPL is completed, delete data.Inventory and data.WarehouseInventory records for StockDate. (Records of the last day need to be deleted for final data transfer.) | Academy Data Transfer - Early DT Post Process |

t day need to be deleted for final data transfer.) | Academy Data Transfer - Early DT Post Process |

(1) In daily WRPL target run, Product-Warehouse level targets are calculated. Then they are split in Product-Store level. Before updating the warehouse.ExternalReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels table, we sum Product-Store targets on Product-Warehouse by using active relations stated in the warehouse.ActiveProductStoreWarehouseRelations. Update SP: etl.UpdateWarehouseExternalReorderPointsTable

Before updating the warehouse.ExternalReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels table, we sum Product-Store targets on Product-Warehouse by using active relations stated in the warehouse.ActiveProductStoreWarehouseRelations. Update SP: etl.UpdateWarehouseExternalReorderPointsTable

Tables Updated During Data Transfer from CSV to Staging

All files provided by ASO are taken into the Staging database. For all files, tables in temp and dbo schemas are updated with the data feed. Tables in temp schema are truncated every day and all records in a file inserted into the related table. Update logic for dbo schema changes for each file. Some of them hold the most recent records (like a full snapshot), some of them hold historical data.

Some of them hold the most recent records (like a full snapshot), some of them hold historical data.

### Missing Products and Stores

When a record with unknown ProductCode or StoreCode by master tables, we prefer to keep these records in Maps database. Missing products and stores are inserted into master tables and log tables in order to prevent data loss. Tables that we check for missing products and stores are listed below.

Work Flow for Early and Final Data Transfer

Important Notes:- Deletion should be triggered after RPL and WRPL runs are completed.
- Final CSV job should wait for Early MAPS job to be completed. (Both work on the same tables in Staging database)
- Final MAPS job should wait for Early Post Process job to be completed. (Both work on the same tables in Maps database)
- In order to check whether Early MAPS and Early Post Process jobs are completed or not, the record with the appropriate StockDate in etl.EarlyDataTransferRuns table is used.

Bu dokümanın amacı parquet formatındaki envanter verisini oluştururken izlediğimiz adımları anlatmaktır.

Temel olarak iki data kaynağımız var.

1. SQL Database
2. Parquet files

İki data kaynağı için de izlediğimiz yol şu şekilde.

1. Mevcut inventory_byweek parquet dosyasını baz alarak external Hive tablosu oluşturulur.
2. Ingest etmek istediğimiz veri için ikinci bir Hive tablosu oluşturulur.
3. İkinci oluşturduğumuz tablodan SELECT edilip ilk tabloya INSERT edilir.

İkinci adımda gereken Hive tablosu oluşturulurken data kaynağına göre izlediğimiz yol değişiyor. Eğer SQL Database'deki veriyi import ediyorsak Sqoop kullanıyoruz. Parquet için ise ilk adımdaki gibi doğrudan Hive tablosu oluşturuyoruz.

# define column mapping here. partition columns must be defined separately
COLUMN_MAPPING="productid int,
                storeid int,\
                netstock double,\
                netincomingstock double,\
                availablestock double,\
                totalstock double,\
                incomingstock double,\
                incomingstockfromsupplier double,\
                incomingstockfromwarehouse double,\
                incomingstockfromcrossdock double,\
                incomingstockfromotherstore double,\
                openorder double,\
                openordertosupplier double,\
                openordertowarehouse double,\
                openordertocrossdock double,\
                openorderfromotherstore double,\
                incomingstockintransit double,\
                incomingstockintransitfromsupplier double,\
                incomingstockintransitfromwarehouse double,\
                incomingstockintransitfromcrossdock double,\

content:
ingstockintransitfromwarehouse double,\
                incomingstockintransitfromcrossdock double,\
                incomingstockintransitfromotherstore double,\
                outgoingstock double,\
                outgoingstockforcustomer double,\
                outgoingstockforotherstore double,\
                unavailablestock double,\
                displaystock double,\
                waitingstock double,\
                returnstocktowarehouse double,\
                returnstocktosupplier double,\
                returnedstock double,\
                storageroomstock double,\
                departmentstock double,\
                backorderstock double,\
                inventorydate string"
PARTITION_MAPPING="inventoryyear int, inventoryweek int"
PARQUET_LOCATION="s3://invent-academy-datastore/parquet/inventory_byweek/"

content:
# import data with sqoop. create hive table
"${SQOOP}" import \
  --connect "${SQLDBCONNETION}" \
  --query "SELECT [Date] as inventorydate,[ProductId],[StoreId],[NetStock],[NetIncomingStock], [AvailableStock], [TotalStock], [IncomingStock], [IncomingStockFromSupplier], [IncomingStockFromWarehouse], [IncomingStockFromCrossDock], [IncomingStockFromOtherStore], [OpenOrder], [OpenOrderToSupplier], [OpenOrderToWarehouse], [OpenOrderToCrossDock], [OpenOrderFromOtherStore], [IncomingStockInTransit], [IncomingStockInTransitFromSupplier], [IncomingStockInTransitFromWarehouse], [IncomingStockInTransitFromCrossDock], [IncomingStockInTransitFromOtherStore], [OutgoingStock], [OutgoingStockForCustomer], [OutgoingStockForOtherStore], [UnavailableStock], [DisplayStock], [WaitingStock], [ReturnStockToWarehouse], [ReturnStockToSupplier], [ReturnedStock], [StorageRoomStock], [DepartmentStock], [BackorderStock] FROM Academy.data.Inventory2017 WHERE \$CONDITIONS" \

metadata.title: SQL/Parquet to Hadoop Data Ingestion with Sqoop and Hive

content:
oomStock], [DepartmentStock], [BackorderStock] FROM Academy.data.Inventory2017 WHERE \$CONDITIONS" \
  --target-dir "/user/hadoop/INVENTORY" \
  --username "username" --password "*" \
  -m 1 --hive-import --hive-table "${DB}.hdfs_inventory"

content:
-- create external table from parquet/inventory_byweek
drop table if exists ${hiveconf:DB_NAME}.inventory_byweek;
create external table if not exists ${hiveconf:DB_NAME}.inventory_byweek (
        productid int,
        storeid int,
        netstock double,
        netincomingstock double,
        availablestock double,
        totalstock double,
        incomingstock double,
        incomingstockfromsupplier double,
        incomingstockfromwarehouse double,
        incomingstockfromcrossdock double,
        incomingstockfromotherstore double,
        openorder double,
        openordertosupplier double,
        openordertowarehouse double,
        openordertocrossdock double,
        openorderfromotherstore double,
        incomingstockintransit double,
        incomingstockintransitfromsupplier double,
        incomingstockintransitfromwarehouse double,
        incomingstockintransitfromcrossdock double,
        incomingstockintransitfromotherstore double,

metadata.title: SQL/Parquet to Hadoop Data Ingestion with Sqoop and Hive

content:
incomingstockintransitfromcrossdock double,
        incomingstockintransitfromotherstore double,
        outgoingstock double,
        outgoingstockforcustomer double,
        outgoingstockforotherstore double,
        unavailablestock double,
        displaystock double,
        waitingstock double,
        returnstocktowarehouse double,
        returnstocktosupplier double,
        returnedstock double,
        storageroomstock double,
        departmentstock double,
        backorderstock double,
        inventorydate string
    )
    partitioned by (
        inventoryyear int,
        inventoryweek int
    )
    stored as parquet
    location 's3://invent-academy-datastore/parquet/inventory_byweek'
    tblproperties ('parquet.compress'='snappy');

content: tba

Seasonality calculation is done for different levels; department - class - subclass - base. By base we mean product id or style-diff. For items with style-diff; we calculate the seasonality for the whole style-diff. Aggregation levels for product id's can be seen from the output (AggregationLevel.rds is the current version). Sales data is aggregated weekly. We are calculating the upper level seasonalities just to use them as an approximation of seasonality of a product belonging to that level.

Therefore aggregation over class - subclass - department is not done until the rest of the cleaning ends. In some subclasses (for example hard coolers) SKU count varies dramatically during the year; in summer there are around 100 different SKU's, while it is just 60 in the winter. Even though that subclass performs better in summer; seasonality curve of the subclass does not represent seasonality curve of an SKU.

There are 4 different steps in the calculation:

ass does not represent seasonality curve of an SKU.

There are 4 different steps in the calculation:

- Cleaning the sales data
- Tagging
- Promo shifts - outlier detection
- Seasonality coefficients

Handling 2020-Covid Year

Method1: The 2020 year is removed and previous and next weeks are merged like the data is continuing. Prior years' names are shifted to one ahead. Such as 2019 to 2020, 2018 to 2019. Special days are shifted in the same way. If the jointed week's DemandAdjusted difference is higher than 2 times, those items are removed from the data.

Method2: Problematic weeks predicted and filled with prophet outputs, and given as the input data to same pipeline.

Cleaning the Sales Data

filled with prophet outputs, and given as the input data to same pipeline.

Cleaning the Sales Data

For some products, start date might not be the first sales date. When analyzing the data, we had come across to some dummy sales; which means a sale happens then there is a long break until the next sale. Therefore there is a need to decide the start date. We check the mean sales and standard deviation of sales for each product for each week. Therefore if the starting week of an item has less than (mean - standard deviation)sales; we eliminate it. This works as a loop until there is nothing to eliminate.

There is a need for calendar shifting here. We assume there is 52 weeks in a year (in reference to retail calendar: [https://nrf.com/resources/4-5-4-calendar](https://nrf.com/resources/4-5-4-calendar)). So, 53 week years are shifted back by one week and first week is eliminated. This way Black Friday comes to 47th week and Christmas becomes 50-51th weeks.

Tagging

s eliminated. This way Black Friday comes to 47th week and Christmas becomes 50-51th weeks.

Tagging

Tagging decides on the products to get into the seasonality run:

- If a product has less than 52 weeks, it cannot get into the seasonality run
- If an item is not selling for the last 4 weeks, we consider it dead
- If there is a jump in the sales data (no sales for 8 weeks), we assume there is a problem in the product (might be an in-stock problem)
- If an item sells less than 2 for a week; it will be susceptible to randomness highly, therefore they are eliminate
- If an item sells 65% of total sales in one month, we need to use a different seasonality calculation (we try to smooth the coefficients in this one)

Also some tags gives us information about the sales pattern:

- If sales mean > 200, volume is high
- If sales mean > 2*standard deviation, stable
- If there is a sale every week after the start, consistent
- Full years

*standard deviation, stable
- If there is a sale every week after the start, consistent
- Full years

There are some tags about the monthly sales patterns. For this, weekly sales should be aggregated to monthly sales. For this, we are referring to retail calendar and using 4 - 4 - 5 schedule (January 4 weeks, February 4 weeks, March 5 weeks and goes on). This will make like-for-like analysis possible with same number of weekends over the years for each year. Since we will be trying to understand the relation of sales between each month, we'll get the 4/5 of sales for months with 5 weeks.

If standard deviation of month percentage is less than 0.04, we call the item as year around. If it is more than 0.04, we call it seasonal. There are different seasonal patterns but based on the peaks, we name the most prevalent sales patterns with 2 peaks.

Promo Shifts - Outlier Detection

the peaks, we name the most prevalent sales patterns with 2 peaks.

Promo Shifts - Outlier Detection

To depromo the sales data, we are currently using Prophet (for details Taylor(2017), for quick-start [https://facebook.github.io/prophet/docs/quick_start.html](https://facebook.github.io/prophet/docs/quick_start.html)).

Prophet is easy to configure and easy to interpret. It is possible to use it for forecasting; but for now we are just using its several features. We are giving promo prices as holidays (3 different holidays; hard promo for 0.25%, medium promo for 15%-25% and low promo for 5%-15% discount, ASP is calculated based on 26 weeks) to the model and finding the price coefficients for each week. Just using the promo amount might result with negative coefficients when there is a stock-out; therefore we assume sales will be increasing if there is a promo. Therefore promo coefficient will only be used if sales are higher than mean.

One option is doing a grid search (it is possible via spark since it takes a lot of time) for the parameters, but currently we are using the correlation between price and ASP * (-1/2) as holidays prior scale parameter. That parameter limits the effect of the price change. Black Friday and New Year's weeks are not considered as promo weeks. It is possible to consider them as additional regressors but I am not inclined to solve Black Friday and New Year's eve problem with a time series model (according to Ali et al. 2009, even though it is not possible to beat time series model in periods without promotions, regression trees can provide up to 65% improvement if there is a promotion). Having price multipliers > 3 didn't work out well (and it is not easy to incorporate into other models; it heavily distorts the original series) and that kind of price multipliers ended up with worse results in predicting

ts the original series) and that kind of price multipliers ended up with worse results in predicting. I would prefer to have trend and seasonality as the main predictors in normal times (for interpretability purposes); therefore I haven't used price as an additional regressor.

After getting the de-promo sales quantity (by dividing the sales quantity to price multiplier), we are using an outlier detection module. I have considered several options but since we need to detect and replace outliers for up to 4 years, we are using tso from forecast package in R).

need to detect and replace outliers for up to 4 years, we are using tso from forecast package in R).

- DB-SCAN method was an early candidate; but it would be clustering without considering the time dimension. I would like to be able to call a sale of 15 between 1's as an outlier while call it normal when it is between 14's.
- Replace value functionality made my life easier.
- A better candidate was tsoutliers function from tsoutliers package. It detects different type of outliers and transient change + additive outliers were quite helpful to understand the data. But unluckily the function is slow; it is not possible to run it for 30k pairs on a local machine.

Seasonality Coefficients

on is slow; it is not possible to run it for 30k pairs on a local machine.

Seasonality Coefficients

Our general approach is using a moving average of 6 with seasonality and price coefficients to find MAPE and decide on the goodness of fit. We are using multiplicative seasonality, therefore when a method is giving additive seasonality, we are log-transforming the underlying data and get the multipliers (for example, for STL that transformation is needed).

First test is done for products with 3+ years of data; seasonality coefficients were extracted from previous years and used for predicting last 52 weeks. There were 4 candidates:

- TBATS
- Prophet
- STL
- Standard
- Combination

predicting last 52 weeks. There were 4 candidates:

- TBATS
- Prophet
- STL
- Standard
- Combination

TBATS had given the best results out of all. But the problem was its run-time and it didn't provide enough difference from second best (STL); therefore we eliminated it from use. Similary using Prophet for second time (after getting the price coefficients) didn't yield enough reduction in MAPE compared to its run-time, therefore we eliminated them too. Even though test was done for 3+ years of data; it was just an explarotary analysis. We are using the seasonality coefficients from whole data.

STL is the main function we are using therefore I would provide some details about how it works. Basically it is based on a Loess smoothing (Cleveland et al., 1990). Loess smoothing is a local regression, fitting a weight (usually tri-cube) based on distance, then fitting a polynomial degree d (mostly 1-2). STL consists of two loops, inner and outer. Inner:

then fitting a polynomial degree d (mostly 1-2). STL consists of two loops, inner and outer. Inner:

- Detrend
- Groups the data based on weeks in each cycle (therefore needs at least 2 cycles). Smooth them using Loess.
- Low-pass filtering; get the smoothed whole series. Two moving average smoothing and one Loess smoothing.
- Detrend the smoothed sub-cycle
- Deseasonalize
- Smooth values

Outer loop:

- Get trend and seasonal values (this trend will be used for detrending in the inner loop)
- Put robustness weight based on the distance to mean (for outliers etc.)

This ends up with changing seasonality coefficients for each year. Since the test in last 52 weeks showed STL still works better than standard, we can say that STL is over-fitting to last year.

Standard uses decompose function; which is based on moving averages.

Combination is combination of seasonality multipliers from different methods.

d on moving averages.

Combination is combination of seasonality multipliers from different methods.

Seasonality coefficients are calculated for 2 different groups: Products with more than two years of data and products with less than 2 years but more than 1 years of data.

For 2+ years:

- Use STL - standard and combination. Use the one with lowest MAPE.

For 1-2 years:

- Use Prophet and TSLM functions (TSLM is basically linear regression model with week numbers and trend as regressors).
- These tend to give really low MAPE. But coefficients can be pretty high (like 16). That means they are over-fitting. Therefore we need to smooth them.
- For Prophet we are using just Loess smoothing (since coefficients weren't as high as TSLM). For TSLM we are using something similar to STL's low-pass filtering. Two moving averages of 11 and one Loess smoothing.

At the end, coefficients with best MAPE are selected as the seasonality coefficient.

ess smoothing.

At the end, coefficients with best MAPE are selected as the seasonality coefficient.

Note:Using 1 year data tends to over-fit a lot. To understand the effect, I have conducted an experiment with 50 random products. Extracted seasonality from less than 2 years and used that seasonality for predicting the next year. The smoothing in Loess brought 7-8% of reduction in MAPE (31% to 28%). TSLM with smoothing adds another 4%. Adding the linear combination to the mix and selecting the best ends up with 20% reduction in MAPE (25%).

Note:Smoothing the TSLM brings arounds 30% reduction in MAPE (37% to 27%) for the 50 product sample.

Selecting the Best Model

ings arounds 30% reduction in MAPE (37% to 27%) for the 50 product sample.

Selecting the Best Model

For the pairs having more than 3 years data; we have used 1 year of data as test to examine the effect of longer time-span. As far as we have seen, generally more data gives better approximations. But that might not be the case always. It might be due to a anomaly (which wasn't solved completely) in the previous data. Therefore if MAPE is above 20%; we shorten the data set. We are using in-stock rates and clearence sales as an indicator.  If there is a period with low in-stock rates or relatively high clearance sales we skip that part. We handle this through breaking the sales data into divisions. After a problematic period, a new division starts.

Special Days

It is possible to incorporate special days to the system through Prophet. It would be used similar to depromoing the sales data. Easter weeks should be given as an additional holiday to the model.

ar to depromoing the sales data. Easter weeks should be given as an additional holiday to the model.

If you are just interested to find if a specific date has an affect in an SKU, you can just put it as an holiday and check the coefficients. If holiday coefficient for the event is >1, it is possible to say that SKU will be susceptible to that event. It can be used for an alarm and a holiday multiplier.

Articles:

Ali, Özden Gür, et al. "SKU demand forecasting in the presence of promotions." *Expert Systems with Applications* 36.10 (2009): 12340-12348.

Cleveland, Robert B., et al. "STL: A Seasonal-Trend Decomposition." *Journal of Official Statistics* 6.1 (1990): 3-73.

Taylor, Sean J., and Benjamin Letham. "Forecasting at scale. 2017." *URL:*[https://facebookincubator](https://facebookincubator)*. github. io/prophet* (2017).

# Terms

## Stored Procedure

DTInteraction_TransferProducts

DTInteraction_TransferStores

# Flow

Spark kodlarımızı çalıştırdığımız AWS Elastic MapReduce (EMR) cluster'larında zaman zaman aldığımız bir hata var. Bu hatanın sebebi S3'te fiziksel olarak yer alan dosyalarla EMR'ın metadata olarak sakladığı dosya kayıtları arasında uyumsuzluk olması. Bunu bir örnekle şu şekilde açıklayabiliriz: S3'te invent-academy-datastore/dataadresinde forecast-resultsisimli bir klasör olduğunu düşünelim. Eğer bu klasör bir Spark job'ı sonucu oluştuysa, EMR kendi veri tabanında bu klasör için bir metadata kaydı oluşturuyor. Yani S3'te fiziksel olarak invent-academy-datastore/data/forecast-resultsklasörünü görebildiğimiz gibi, EMR metadatasında da bu klasöre ait bir kayıt görüyoruz. Eğer fiziksel olanla metadata arasında bir uyumsuzluk olursa, örneğin S3'ten manuel olarak klasör silinir ama metadata güncellenmezse, EMRFS ConsistencyException diye isimlendirilen bir hata ile karşılaşıyoruz.

metadata güncellenmezse, EMRFS ConsistencyException diye isimlendirilen bir hata ile karşılaşıyoruz.

Cluster konfigürasyonunda bu hatanın alınmasını engelleyecek bir takım önlemler var ve çoğu zaman çalışıyor. Ancak nadir de olsa bu önlemlere rağmen bu hata ile karşılaşıyoruz. Bu durumda yapılması gerekenleri aşağıda listeliyorum.

## Hatanın Kaynağının Belirlenmesi

EMR ile çalıştırdığımız kodların loglarına bakarak hataya neyin sebep olduğunu anlayabiliyoruz. Bunun için AWS EMR konsolundan ilgili cluster'a ve ona ait "step"lere ulaşmamız gerekiyor. Buraya gitmek için izlediğimiz yol şu şekilde: [console.aws.amazon.com/](http://console.aws.amazon.com/) > Services > EMR > Clusters > academy_cluster > Steps. Burada "Log Files" kısmından hata alan step'in "stdout" loguna tıklıyoruz. Açılan metnin en sonunda hatanın sebebi gözüküyor.

dan hata alan step'in "stdout" loguna tıklıyoruz. Açılan metnin en sonunda hatanın sebebi gözüküyor.

Hata mesajında hangi klasörde inconsistency yaşandığı bilgisi yer alıyor. Yukarıdaki örnekte *invent-academy-datastore/model-data/seasonality-multipliers*klasöründe sorun yaşamışız. Bunun düzeltilmesi için cluster'ın master node'una komut satırı ile bağlanmak ve bir komut çalıştırmak gerekiyor. Bu bağlantıyı Airflow server'ı aracılığı ile yapıyoruz. Bağlantıyı kuracak kişinin Airflow tarafında "authorized_user" olarak belirlenmesi gerekiyor, i.e. airflow sunucusuna ssh yapabilmesi gerekiyor. Bağlantı için izlenecek adımlar şu şekilde, ssh bağlantısı yapabilen bir komut satırı programı kullanılarak:

```bash
ssh -l <USERNAME_HERE> airflow.us.prod.inventanalytics.com -i .ssh/id_rsa_airflow
```

```bash
# this command asks for sudo password
sudo su - airflow
```

```bash
ssh -l hadoop <CLUSTER_DNS_HERE>
```

```bash
emrfs sync s3://<FOLDER_PATH_HERE>
```

Bu işlem biraz vakit alır. İşlem tamamlandığında belirtilen adresteki dosyalar ile metadata senkronize edilmiş olur.

- Everyday the table is resolved at 00.30 AM CT.
- Name of the job is Academy Interaction Resolver
- The job saves previous day's snapshot record to _prev table and truncates the target table and inserts snapshot of valid hold out quantities.
- The changes done before 00.30 AM CT, will be effective in the next day's replenishment run.

Holdout Quantity

Safety stock caps:

1 - Safety stock value is capped between 0.4 and 1.612312 times of cover forecast.

After target_v00, we have 3 different steps in calculating the final target.

1 - Manual fixes for our engine (ends with target_v99)

2 - Constraints put per request of the customer (ends with target_v999)

3 - Hard caps (ends with target_v9999)

First part:

a. MinTargetDOS: Parametric. Minimum target is daily forecast * 15 days

b. Few available days: Parametric. If available days (can be found in the forecast output) is less than a limit; max is 1.5*sales in forecast (can be found in forecast output)

c. High seasonality multipliers: Parametric. If seasonality multiplier is over 7, sales in forecast*2 is the max cap

d. Sales without inventory: Parametric. If positive stock count < available days*0.8, cap with 0.88*cover period forecast

ntory: Parametric. If positive stock count < available days*0.8, cap with 0.88*cover period forecast

e. Sales count 1: Parametric. If positive sales count =1 and positive stock count > 20, cap with 2 (this cap should consider sales patterns of products; will be changed in a near future)

f. Store product max quantity: Input from table. Store - product - max quantity.

g. Special item cap: Input from a table with columns store - product - cap. Calculated weekly for expensive items. Stores are ordered by target_v99; then separated into groups. For each group 95th percentile is the upper limit.

h. Model after item cap: If there is no sale of a product in a store and forecast is calculated based on a model after item; use presentation level as the target instead of model after information.

Second part:

a. Long cover period cap

tion level as the target instead of model after information.

Second part:

a. Long cover period cap

b. Longer cover cap for special departments: a-b should have its input from a table. Both caps the safety stock when cover time is over 14. Target cannot exceed forecast cover period + 0.3*forecast cover period.

c. Store product max target: Based on client's request. Input from table. Store - product - max quantity - start date - end date - is deleted - deletion date

d. Presentation level

Third part:

a. Freeze target: Input from table. Store - product - freeze target - start date - end date - is deleted - deletion date. This was used during the holiday period.

b. Product max quantity: Input from a table with columns product - cap - start date - end date - is deleted - deletion date. This constraint is in the end because it might be 0.

> In this page, Academy specific input-output and parameter related details will be written. For detailed information on how to calculate SOQ see run from ROP to SOQ page

# Input Tables

## Common Tables

model.ProductPackages:Different packages of products are stated.

data.FamiliesByProduct:Items in sub-item relation are grouped using family id. Main item in a family is indicated as IsMain = 1

## Store Replenishment

replenishment.CustomerPairs:

Populated by inner joining of the following three tables:

1. Active product-store combinations listed in AcademyStaging.dbo.ITEM_LOC table (STATUS = 'A')
2. Rolled out product-store combinations listed in AcademyReporting.dbo.ReplenishmentCustomerPairs
3. Product-store combinations with a target listed in replenishment.ExternalReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels
4. Active product-store relations listed in replenishment.ActiveProductStoreRelations if the target date is between activity start and end dates

metadata.title: Maps Replenishment and Result Transfer Details

content:
replenishment.ActiveProductStoreRelations if the target date is between activity start and end dates

replenishment.ExternalReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels:ROP and OUTL values that will be used. Populated in DT with AcademyReporting.dbo.ReorderPointsTempTable

replenishment.OrderablePackagesByStore:Indicates which package can be sent to a store.

AcademyReporting.dbo.MaxSoqThresholds:Maximum SOQ thresholds that are used during result transfer.

replenishment.SupplySourcesByPair: Supply sources for product-store combinations.

replenishment.FrequenciesByPair: The frequencies of reviewing product-store combinations for replenishment.

1. Active product-warehouse combinations listed in warehouse.ActiveProductWarehouseRelations

3. Product-warehouse combinations with a target listed in warehouse.ExternalReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels

warehouse.ExternalReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels:Populated in DT with AcademyReporting.dbo.DC_RPL_TargetTempTable. Product-Store targets, that are listed in DC_RPL_TargetTempTable, are summed on Product-Warehouse by using active relations stated in the warehouse.ActiveProductStoreWarehouseRelations.

warehouse.OrderablePackagesByWarehouse:Indicates which package can be sent to a warehouse

AcademyReporting.dbo.DC_RPL_MaxSoqThresholds:Maximum SOQ thresholds that are used during result transfer.

| ParameterName | Value | Explanation |
| --- | --- | --- |
| ApplyCompleteToMinimumForPackedProducts | False | While adjusting SOQs with package sizes, it doesn't try to complete critical stocks. |
| ConsiderLatestOrdersDuringEarlyRun | True | When RunOption = 1 (Early Run), the latest exported orders are added to total stock. |
| IsSuccessfulPreprocessMust | False | If the preprocess module fails, RPL continues without fail. In the preprocess module, new family relations are extracted and written into a temporary table in AcademyReporting database. For detailed information: sub-item relation section sub-item relation section |
| RunFromReorderPointsToSuggestedOrderQuantities | True | The scope of the run. |
| SaveReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels | True | ROP values are recorded during the RPL run. |
| SaveSuggestedOrderQuantitiesWithoutPackageAdjustment | True | Raw SOQ values are recorded during the RPL run. |
| SimilarProductsDefined | True | Stocks of sub-items are merged. |

metadata.title: Maps Replenishment and Result Transfer Details

content:
e recorded during the RPL run. |
| SimilarProductsDefined | True | Stocks of sub-items are merged. |
| UseCustomerPairs | True | RPL runs with product-store combinations listed in the replenishment.CustomerPairs |
| UseExternalReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels | True | ROP-OUTL values are fetched from the replenishment.ExternalReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels |

The parameters not listed above used with default values in Maps codebase. For instance, default package round-up thresholds are used for Academy. (MultiPackageCompleteWeight: 0.2, MultiPackageCompleteWeightForStockOut: 0.01)

# Output Tables

## Store Replenishment

replenishment.SuggestedOrderQuantitiesWithoutPackageAdjustment: Raw SOQ results.

replenishment.SuggestedOrderQuantities: SOQ results that are adjusted according to packages. (Finalized SOQ values.)

AcademyReporting.dbo.AdjustedSuggestedOrderQuantities:Adjusted SOQ results according to Max SOQ Thresholds.

replenishment.ExportedOrders:Results exported to be shared with the customer. We only keep one-month results in this table.

replenishment.CustomerPicks:RunId exported to be shared with the customer. The latest run is indicated as IsLatestRun = 1

## DC Replenishment

warehouse.SuggestedOrderQuantitiesWithoutMinMaxAdjustment:Raw SOQ results.

warehouse.SuggestedOrderQuantitiesWithoutPackageAdjustment: SOQ results that are adjusted according to minimum order quantities.

warehouse.SuggestedOrderQuantities: SOQ results that are adjusted according to packages. (Finalized SOQ values.)

AcademyReporting.dbo.AdjustedWarehouseSuggestedOrderQuantities:Adjusted SOQ results according to Max SOQ Thresholds.

Sub-Item Relations

metadata.title: Maps Replenishment and Result Transfer Details

content:
d to be shared with the customer. The latest run is indicated as IsLatestRun = 1

Sub-Item Relations

During RPL, a preprocess module is running. For Academy, in this module, sub-item family relations are extracted. If an exception is thrown during the preprocess module, RPL continues to run. A mail about the exception is sent to the academy-data mail group. In this case, python code to extract sub item families should be run manually.

We update data.FamiliesByProduct with a 1-day lag. Once we get new sub item files, we use them to extract new relations. However, we don't put new relations immediately in production. We update etl.FamiliesByProductTempTable on day-1. A control process works to detect changes in family relations. If something is wrong, etl.FamiliesByProductTempTable should be updated manually.

We update the family relations in production (data.FamiliesByProduct) one day later.

metadata.title: Maps Replenishment and Result Transfer Details

content:
ated manually.

We update the family relations in production (data.FamiliesByProduct) one day later.

Day 1: After daily data feed, new family relations are extracted. They are held in a temporary table. The control process works to detect changes between family relations in production and temporary relations. If anything wrong is detected, temporary relations are updated to fix problematic cases.

Day 2: Family relations in production are updated using temporary family relations. And the processes in Day 1 are completed.

# Result Transfer

Result transfer is triggered after RPL and WRPL algorithms are completed. It selects runs to export, prepares the result tables, and writes the results into sftp folder.

## Parameters

metadata.title: Maps Replenishment and Result Transfer Details

content:
runs to export, prepares the result tables, and writes the results into sftp folder.

## Parameters

| ParameterName | Value | Explanation |
| --- | --- | --- |
| ExportScriptArgs | Changes according to sftp folder we want to put results | Indicates which folder results will be put. For final in production, it will be "final prod" |
| IsStoreReplenishmentMust | True | For result transfer, the latest store replenishment run with the same target date should be successfully ended. |
| IsWarehouseReplenishmentMust | False | For result transfer, the latest warehouse replenishment run with the same target date doesn't need to end successfully. |

## RunId Selection

Function client.GetStoreReplenishmentRunId is used to get store replenishment run id. For Academy, the latest store replenishment run with the same target date as result transfer target date is selected to share results only if it is ended successfully.

metadata.title: Maps Replenishment and Result Transfer Details

content:
t date as result transfer target date is selected to share results only if it is ended successfully.

Function client.GetWarehouseReplenishmentRunId is used to get warehouse replenishment run id. For Academy, the latest warehouse replenishment run with the same target date as result transfer target date is selected to share results only if it is ended successfully.

## Run Condition

Because parameter IsStoreReplenishmentMust is True for Academy,if the latest RPL run doesn't finish successfully, the result transfer algorithm throws an exception and results won't be shared. However, since parameter IsWarehouseReplenishmentMust is False, even if the latest WRPL run fails, store replenishment results will be shared.

## Result Preparation

A. First of all, etl.DCStoreProductResults, etl.POStoreProductResults, and etl.NewStoreSKU tables are truncated.

B. Store Replenishment

metadata.title: Maps Replenishment and Result Transfer Details

content:
esults, etl.POStoreProductResults, and etl.NewStoreSKU tables are truncated.

B. Store Replenishment

1. For selected RunId, SOQ results are fetched and adjusted according to max SOQ thresholds indicated in AcademyReporting.dbo.MaxSoqThresholds. These adjusted SOQ values are also saved into AcademyReporting.dbo.AdjustedSuggestedOrderQuantities.
2. For pairs in CustomerPairs with no SOQ value, 0 is added as a result.
3. Results are split into two groups according to their supply sources indicated in replenishment.SupplySourcesByPair.
4. Results of product-store combinations with 'Warehouse' or no supply source value are inserted into etl.DCStoreProductResults.
5. For product-store combinations with 'Crossdock' or 'Supplier';Their frequencies are checked from AcademyReporting.etl.SupplierFrequencies. Results of product-store combinations with active frequency for the target date are inserted into etl.POStoreProductResults.

metadata.title: Maps Replenishment and Result Transfer Details

content:
combinations with active frequency for the target date are inserted into etl.POStoreProductResults.

C. DC Replenishment → If selected run id equals to 0 (no successful WRPL run) result preparation of WRPL is skipped.

1. For selected RunId, SOQ results are fetched and adjusted according to max SOQ thresholds indicated in AcademyReporting.dbo.MaxSoqThresholds. These adjusted SOQ values are also saved into AcademyReporting.dbo.AdjustedSuggestedOrderQuantities
2. For product-warehouse combinations in CustomerPairs with no SOQ value, 0 is added as a result.
3. For all product-warehouse combinations, their frequencies are checked from warehouse.FrequenciesByProductWarehouse.
4. Results of product-warehouse combinations with active frequency for the target date are inserted into etl.POStoreProductResults.

D. etl.NewStoreSKU is populated with all item-location combinations in etl.DCStoreProductResults and etl.POStoreProductResults

## Export Mechanism

metadata.title: Maps Replenishment and Result Transfer Details

content:
ocation combinations in etl.DCStoreProductResults and etl.POStoreProductResults

## Export Mechanism

Once result tables to be shared are prepared, the export powershell script is triggered.

See detailed information in [Export Mechanism]

This page is created to explain roll out process in Academy.

In the beginning of the ASO store replenishment process we've selected 13 departments as pilot and created all tables, SPs etc. using that pilot list. Since it was a fast and simple approach, the pilot list was not easily manageable for new items and new products(warehouse rpl etc.)

Therefore we've created below design. This design is not only created for new item roll out but also for managing overall system.

## New Item Roll Out Process

### PRODUCTION

In order to understand the logic, we will first describe our current system.

Everyday our production replenishment runs for SKUs that satisfy following conditions:

USABLE_IND = 1 & ACTIVE_IND = 1 &  RPL_FC_IND = 1 & RPL_IND = 1

that satisfy following conditions:

USABLE_IND = 1 & ACTIVE_IND = 1 &  RPL_FC_IND = 1 & RPL_IND = 1

This is logic detects SKUs only. We need to detect SKU-location combinations. Every item-location that has a record in either sales or inventory table in most recent 200 days is selected.

In the final output we handle family relations. Basically, all sub items is converted to main items in the final output.

For more information, please check *AcademyReporting.[dbo].[StoreRPLPairSelection]* stored procedure.

### TO BE IN PRODUCTION

Everyday after the production run we take a similar run for to-be-roll out items. Those items are selected as:

USABLE_IND = 1 & ACTIVE_IND = 1 &  RPL_FC_IND = 1 & RPL_IND = 0

The remaining logic applied after above conditions is same as Production. For more information please check *AcademyReporting. [dbo].[RollOutReviewSelection].*

## Item Submission Process

ASO submits new items via [Item Roll Out Files] page.

## Item Submission Process

ASO submits new items via [Item Roll Out Files] page.

In the spreadsheets they submit SKU codes. Take those SKU codes into a csv with a header as ProductCode. Following is a sample code:

```text
require(data.table)
temp <- fread("Wave 3.1. Item RollOut.csv")
# Zero padding
temp[, ProductCode := sprintf("%09d", ProductCode)]
# Sometimes they submit duplicate values
temp <- unique(temp)
fwrite(temp, "Wave3.1.ItemRollOut_Padding.csv")
```

Then I copy paste padded SKU codes into following SQL query

```sql

,'013278122'

### Roll-out Items In Production Process

There are two types of items:

1. Already submitted before to be included in to-be roll out process. (i.e. New departments)
2. It's one of the departments that is previously rolled out. Therefore it'll be in production directly.

#### 1.  Already Submitted

USE AcademyReporting

DROP TABLE #temp
SELECT
	*
INTO #temp
FROM AcademyReporting.parameters.ProductScope
WHERE
	ACTIVE_IND = 1
	AND RPL_IND = 0
	AND RPL_FC_IND = 1
	AND USABLE_IND = 1
	AND Notes = 'Wave0 - Wave1 April 13th'

UPDATE #temp
SET RPL_IND = 1,
	RPL_STARTDATE = '2019-05-03',
	RPL_ENDDATE = '2050-01-01',
	ModifiedDate = GETDATE(),
	Notes = 'Wave 0 & 1 April,13 - RPL turn-on'

-- Do not forget to set active indicator of old records to 0
UPDATE AcademyReporting.parameters.ProductScope SET ACTIVE_IND = 0 WHERE ProductId IN (SELECT ProductId FROM #temp)

# Target Lookahead / Early Season Push Parameter

## Objective & Logic

Target values anticipate upcoming increases in sales and rise accordingly to make sure orders will arrive just in time to satisfy demand.

- This "just in time" characteristic assumes a smoothly operating supply chain that is never stretched beyond capacity, however, during peak periods, when orders are heavy, both DC and Store personnel may fall behind in handling high order volumes

s, when orders are heavy, both DC and Store personnel may fall behind in handling high order volumes

To compensate for this problem, the system supports a parameter called lookahead / early season push, which specifies the number of future weeks over which to calculate Inventory Targets; it then takes the maximum target over that period and uses it for the current period. With this approach, the system pushes the inventory earlier.

The system will create multiple Target values by shifting the date by one week for each Store-SKU combination.

Let's assume this is the forecast output and the cover period is 3 weeks.

In this case, Target_W1 will be calculated by using week-1 to week-3, target_w2 will be calculated by using week-2 to week-4 and so on.

In the end, we will have a table like this:

The default lookahead parameter is 1.

If we make it 2,

S1-P1 will have a final target as MAX(10,12)=12

S1-P2 will have a final target as MAX(10,8)=10

If we make it 3,

ve a final target as MAX(10,12)=12

S1-P2 will have a final target as MAX(10,8)=10

If we make it 3,

S1-P1 will have a final target as MAX(10,12,15)=15

S1-P2 will have a final target as MAX(10,8,8)=10

If we make it 4,

S1-P1 will have a final target as MAX(10,12,15,20)=20

S1-P2 will have a final target as MAX(10,8,8,6)=10

and so on.

# BOP WOS Cap

## Objective & Logic:

The goal is capping Target, especially for Proto-19 stores.

Calculation logic:

It takes the first week of the forecast. Let's call it Forecast_Week_1

then it multiplies Forecast_Week_1 with 3/7. This 3 is hardcoded because when we use actual lead time in the data, it is more than 3. So for the proto-19, we assumed their lead time will be shorter than RMS values

Forecast_LeadTime = Forecast_Week_1 * 3/7

Then the system takes the BOPWOS cap, let's say it is 3.

The system takes the following three weeks of forecast average, which are: mean(Forecast_Week_2,Forecast_Week_3,Forecast_Week_4) = Forecast_AverageAfterFirstWeek

The cap is = Forecast_AverageAfterFirstWeek* BOPWOSCap + Forecast_LeadTime

# Forecast Multiplier

## Objective & Logic

The goal is to affect forecast numbers temporarily.

We don't encourage this module to be used often and it should be used as a last resort.

This module manipulates forecast numbers (either increase or decrease) with a multiplier for a given period.

| EndDate | 2020-01-16 | Date format must be YYYY-MM-DD |

# Service Level Adjuster

## Objective & Logic

The goal is to adjust service levels of a store, particularly if the space in the store is constrained. It can either increase or decrease the targets. There are 6 different values we can consume. They are different scenarios because there is no single service level value. Service levels will be calculated in the engine during the run based on the requested scenario.

## How can I use this capability?

ted in the engine during the run based on the requested scenario.

## How can I use this capability?

Submit a csv file in below format. A template is provided in the *FileManager/ParameterTables_Templates/STORE_SL_ADJUSTER.csv*

The submission process is going to be in two steps (the aim is to remove step #1 going forward):

1. Create task to submit the parameter via template to generate results to review.
2. Create a follow task to approve the results and have Invent apply the parameter in production.

| StartDate | 2020-01-01 | Date format must be YYYY-MM-DD |
| EndDate | 2020-01-16 | Date format must be YYYY-MM-DD |

# Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)

#### How do Invent use Sub-Main relations?

Any parameter submitted for a sub item(P1) is going to be assigned to the main item(P2), automatically. If the sub-main link is broken, the parameter will be automatically removed the previous main item(P2) and remain valid for the sub item(P1).

eter will be automatically removed the previous main item(P2) and remain valid for the sub item(P1).

#### How do Invent handle if there are multiple records submitted?

If there are multiple parameters submitted for a single SKU-Store combination, we will pick one of the records and consume that record in the system. Please see Multiple Records Handling column in the Introduction part of the page. Please see following example for clarification:

Suppose

- A min quantity of 2 is submitted for SKU (P1) & Store (S1) for a given date (D1).
- A min quantity of 3 is submitted for SKU (P1) & Store (S1) for a given date (D1).
- A min quantity of 7 is submitted for SKU (P2) & Store (S1) for a given date (D1) and suppose P2 is sub item of P1.

The value in Multiple Records Handling column is MAX. It means that the system is going to take the maximum of provided submitted parameters. Therefore in this case:

The min value to be used in the system for combination P1-S1-D1 = MAX(2, 3, 7) = 7.

e in this case:

The min value to be used in the system for combination P1-S1-D1 = MAX(2, 3, 7) = 7.

#### How to disable/update production parameters?

To update the parameters, firstly open a disable parameter task then open a parameter submission task. The disable file should contain the exact Note of the corresponding parameter in FileManager/ProductionParameterTables.

#### How to utilize Product Selection / Store Selection in the Manual Adjustment Files?

Invent system uses the Product & Store Selections that are provided in the UI. Therefore before submitting a Product or Store Selection, please make sure the requested selection name is created.

If the request is to apply the parameter across all stores, `StoreSelectionName` should be provided as ALLwhich is a built-in store selection in the system. Therefore there is no need to create a separate selection in the UI if the intention is to apply parameter to all stores.

need to create a separate selection in the UI if the intention is to apply parameter to all stores.

There are three different built-in `ProductSelectionName`:

- If ALL is provided, the parameter is going to be applied to all SKUs on Invent.
- If YR_ALL is provided, there parameter is going to be applied to all SKUs on Invent Year Round Replenishment.
- If SR_ALL is provided, there parameter is going to be applied to all SKUs on Invent Seasonal Replenishment.

This guide explains the necessary steps to add a new table to daily data transfer between Maps and Noob.

There are three steps we need to follow:

1. Creating the new table's metadata (i.e column mapping)
2. Adding the new table to Airflow's daily flow
3. Adding the new table to hive initial load scripts's table list

# Create Glue metadata

First, we should create metadata in AWS Glue. In order to do that, we will use a shell script called hive_create_table

```bash
# Enter table name
TABLE=""

# Define columns here. Example: [{\"Type\": \"int\", \"Name\": \"familyid\"}]
COLUMNS="[{\"Type\": \"int\", \"Name\": \"productid\"}, \
          {\"Type\": \"int\", \"Name\": \"minimumthreshold\"}]"

aws glue create-table --database-name academyemr4parquet --region us-east-1 \
    --table-input "{\"Name\": \"${TABLE,,}\", \"PartitionKeys\": [], \
                  \"Owner\": \"hadoop\", \"StorageDescriptor\": {\"Columns\": \
                  ${COLUMNS}, \"Location\": \
                  \"s3://invent-academy-datastore/parquet/${TABLE,,}\", \
                  \"InputFormat\": \"org.apache.hadoop.hive.ql.io.parquet.MapredParquetInputFormat\", \
                  \"OutputFormat\": \"org.apache.hadoop.hive.ql.io.parquet.MapredParquetOutputFormat\"}}"

# Create external hive table
AWS="/usr/bin/aws"
ORIG_DB="academyemr4parquet"
DB="academyemr02dbad3d"

BUCKET="invent-academy-datastore"

MAP_COLUMN=""

MAP_COLUMN=""

/usr/bin/hive -e "\"CREATE DATABASE IF NOT EXISTS ${DB};\""

MAP_COLUMN=$(aws glue get-tables --database ${ORIG_DB} --region us-east-1 --query "TableList[?Name==\`${TABLE,,}\`].{_COLS:StorageDescriptor.Columns,_PK:PartitionKeys}" --output text | tr -d _COLS | awk '{for(i=1;i<=NF;i=i+2) printf "%s  %s,",$i,$(i+1)}')
MAP_COLUMN=${MAP_COLUMN%,}
echo "drop table if exists ${DB}.${TABLE,,}; \
     create external table if not exists ${DB}.${TABLE,,} \
     (${MAP_COLUMN}) \
     stored as parquet \
     location '${SOURCE}${TABLE,,}' \
     tblproperties ('parquet.compress'='snappy');" > "${SQL_FILE}"

echo "SET hive.exec.dynamic.partition = true;
SET hive.exec.dynamic.partition.mode = nonstrict;
SET hive.exec.max.dynamic.partitions.pernode = 1000;" >> "${SQL_FILE}"

${HIVE} -f "${SQL_FILE}"
rm -f "${SQL_FILE}"

In order to run this script, we can use an EMR cluster's master node. See [EMR File System Consistency Exception] for the details on accessing master node's terminal.

# Add table to Airflow

After running hive create table script, we can add the new table to Airflow. The only thing we need to do is add this table to Airflow variables.

1. Find the variable named academy_maps_to_parquet under Airflow > Admin > Variables
2. Click Edit Record and add the table to tables list.

metadata.title: How to add a new table to Airflow's Maps2parquet process?

content:
_to_parquet under Airflow > Admin > Variables
2. Click Edit Record and add the table to tables list.

> Info: Table name format should be schema.table_name. But, there is an exception for the AcademyReporting DB.Currently we can ingest tables under two schemas, dbo and parameters, from AcademyReporting. If we want to add a table under dbo schema, we should add the table to variables as reporting.TABLE_NAME. For the parameters schema, format should be parameters.TABLE_NAME. This must be fixed in future.

# Add table to hive initial load script

There is a script called hive-initial-load that creates a database tables in hive. Tables are defined in the script. So, we must add the new table to the list in that script.

Script is located under [data-transfer](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy/blob/master/hive-initial-load.sh) repo. Find hive-initial-load.sh here and change the line that tables are defined. We must use lower case while adding the table name.

This document aims to explain the data transfer process between MAPS and Noob systems. The process is orchestrated by Airflow and starts after the MAPS data transfer has finished. A set of MAPS tables are being transferred every day from MS SQL to S3 and stored as a parquet file format. We use Spark, Hive and Sqoop for this process. All process is written as python and bash scripts and meant to be run at Linux servers (more specifically, the master node of an EMR cluster).

# Maps to Noob with Sqoop

There are three sub-processes we need to clarify:

1. Hive Initial Load: Create Hive external tables.
2. Sqoop Import: Select data from MAPS DB and save to HDFS.
3. Hive Import: Import data from HDFS into Hive external tables.

## Hive Initial Load

Please see the [code at GitLab](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy/blob/master/hive-initial-load.sh).

GitLab](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy/blob/master/hive-initial-load.sh).

External tables in Hive is a good fit for our needs because they can store data physically in S3 as parquet format, and when the database is dropped, files continue to exist. So, we create a Hive database and create tables that to be transferred from MAPS.

> Info: Creating a table requires a schema. Instead of defining the table schema as code, we use a service called AWS Glue to keep the table schemas.

> Info: Inventory and Sales tables have partitions on year and week columns. We must specify the partition info for these while creating external tables.

### Tables created during this step:

y the partition info for these while creating external tables.

### Tables created during this step:

- calendar
- cities
- counties
- countries
- datebasedfeatures
- districts
- locations
- models
- productextendedproperties
- productextendedpropertyvalues
- products
- regions
- saleschannels
- salestypes
- states
- storebasedfeatures
- stores
- outlierthreshold
- productclusters
- storespeedclusters
- inventory_byweek
- sales_byweek

## Sqoop Import

Please see the [code at GitLab](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy/blob/master/sqoop-import.sh).

e at GitLab](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy/blob/master/sqoop-import.sh).

The second step of the process is ingesting the data from MS SQL into HDFS. For this, we use a software called Sqoop. It is designed for transferring data between relational SQL databases and Hadoop file systems (as the name suggests, Sq(l)(had)oop). This step selects all data from MAPS, saves it to HDFS and creates temporary Hive tables. These are different from the external tables from the first step. We will use these temporary tables to insert data into external tables. So, they are like a bridge between the new data and existing physical data.

> Info: Products table at MAPS doesn't have the product hierarchy information. We join it with [US-DB-02].[AcademyStaging].[dbo].[Item] to get this information.

archy information. We join it with [US-DB-02].[AcademyStaging].[dbo].[Item] to get this information.

> Info: All tables except Sales and Inventory are transferred as a whole. In other words, we select them without filtering. Since Inventory and Sales tables are partitioned, we don't need to select all data. We get only the last 4 weeks of Sales and 2 weeks of Inventory.

### Tables transferred during this step:

- model.Calendar
- model.Cities
- model.Counties
- model.Countries
- model.Districts
- model.Locations
- model.Models
- model.Products
- model.ProductExtendedProperties
- model.ProductExtendedPropertyValues
- model.Regions
- model.SalesChannels
- model.SalesTypes
- model.States
- model.Stores
- data.Sales
- data.Inventory
- reporting.DateBasedFeatures
- reporting.StoreBasedFeatures
- parameters.OutlierThreshold
- reporting.ProductClusters
- reporting.StoreSpeedClusters

## Hive Import

rameters.OutlierThreshold
- reporting.ProductClusters
- reporting.StoreSpeedClusters

## Hive Import

Please see [the code at GitLab](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy/blob/master/hive-import.sh).

Finally, we will update the existing data at this step. From the first two steps, we have external Hive tables that linked to the physical S3 files, and temporary Hive tables that contain the latest MAPS data. We only need to SELECT data from the temporary table and INSERT into external ones. Final locations of updated physical files are s3://invent-academy-datastore/parquet.

##

## Adding New Tables

You can see [this page](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/academy/pages/1268547681/How+to+add+a+new+table+to+Airflow+s+Maps2parquet+process) to learn how to add new tables to this process.

# Maps to Noob with Spark

w+s+Maps2parquet+process) to learn how to add new tables to this process.

# Maps to Noob with Spark

We also have Spark jobs that executes SQL queries and saves their results as parquet. These jobs are controlled by a script called [db_to_parquet.py](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy/-/blob/master/db_to_parquet.py).

You can see query details in [db_to_parquet.py](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy/-/blob/master/db_to_parquet.py). A summary of queried tables is below.

It is important to not have direct DB connections in noob. If you need to send a query to DB, please add this query here. To add a new query to the list, you need to do two things:

1- Add your query to the TABLESdictionary in [db_to_parquet.py](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy/-/blob/master/db_to_parquet.py) file.

.py](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy/-/blob/master/db_to_parquet.py) file.

2- Append your query name to the list in the Airflow variable academy_maps_to_parquet.spark_tables by following: Airflow > Admin > Variables > academy_maps_to_parquet

Every push to the git repository triggers an auto deployment process via TeamCity. The source repository is invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy and the source branch is master. This branch is protected, hence, only maintainers can push it to the production. The deployment destination is S3. Every file in this repository appears under invent-academy-datastore bucket's lib/data-transfer folder after each deployment.

## Weekly - Monthly Scheduling

If we want to schedule weekly or monthly scheduling, we should make something different than daily.
We should add some code blocks to [client].[RefreshStoredProcedureParameterValues] procedure.

Example:
EXECUTE [client].[FrequentlyStoredProcedureOrganizer]
@Frequency = 'Weekly',
@FrequencyDate = 1,
@StoredProcedureSchema = 'dbo',
@StoredProcedureName = 'GeneratePhantomStockData',
@ParameterIds = ''

StoredProcedureSchema = 'dbo',
@StoredProcedureName = 'GeneratePhantomStockData',
@ParameterIds = ''

1. [client].[FrequentlyStoredProcedureOrganizer] is stored procedure. Which is decide to today is valid for working sp or not?
2. Frequency Date everymonth 15. day or everyweek 1. day
3. Weekly can be 1 <= FrequencyDate <= 7
4. Monthly can be 1 <= FrequencyDate <= 31
5. Parameter Ids are If there is two parameter we should write id's with comma. Example '1,7'
6. Parameter order is important!
7. We can reach parameterId's from [report].[ReportingStoredProcedureParameters]

This page aims to provide the necessary information about the Spark code base of the Academy project. The document has different sections about the job details, codebase location, deployment process, and production usage.

## Overview

We use python/pyspark scripts for customer-specific data processing jobs, calling noob modules, or reporting mostly. These scripts are either scheduled to run every day/week or manually triggered on demand (e.g. to backfill some data when needed).

## Job Details

- item_family_selection.py gets item family data from MAPS and saves as parquet.
- forecast_pair_selection.py gets forecast pairs from MAPS and saves as parquet.
- seasonality.py gets seasonality multipliers from multiple levels and resolves them to the product level. Then saves as parquet.
- outliers_apply_weekly_thresholds.py detects outliers using precomputed outlier thresholds.
- outlier_weekly_threshold_calculation.py calculates outlier thresholds.
- generate_enriched_data.py creates weekly enriched data.
- lost_sales.py calculates weekly lost sales.
- demand_by_product.py aggregates precomputed demand and saves it as parquet.
- model_evaluation.py generates a summary report from weekly forecast results.
- simulation_report_part1(2-3-4).py creates data for simulation dashboard report.
- kpi_report.py creates data for kpi report.
- ls_product.py aggregates precomputed lost sales data and saves as parquet.
- transform_parquet_to_csv.py transforms a parquet file into csv format.

data and saves as parquet.
- transform_parquet_to_csv.py transforms a parquet file into csv format.
- data_control.py checks whether MAPS inventory/sales and parquet inventory/sales are identical.

> Info: Every job gets the required configuration, such as passwords or file paths, from invent-analytics/sparky/noob-pipeline/academy/config.json file.

## Deployment

Every push to the git repository triggers an auto deployment process via TeamCity. The source repository is invent-analytics/sparky/noob-pipeline/academy and the source branch is master. This branch is protected, hence, only maintainers can push it to the production. The deployment destination is S3. Every file in this repository appears under invent-academy-datastore bucket's lib/spark-jobs folder after each deployment.

ository appears under invent-academy-datastore bucket's lib/spark-jobs folder after each deployment.

> Info: In case of a change in deployment location, Airflow must be changed too. There are two things to change in Airflow:Airflow Varible: Airflow > Admin > Variables > academy_emr_step_argsAirflow Source Code: emr_job_flow.py (search for "s3://" in the code)

## Production

We use Airflow to schedule Spark jobs. Airflow creates a Spark cluster with AWS EMR service. Then adds each job as an "EMR Step" sequentially. You can see [academy_emr_job_flow DAG at Airflow UI](https://airflow.us.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?dag_id=academy_emr_job_flow).

content:
After the reclass in 2021, here are some required activities:

- Find new department/class/subclass to create seasonality curve coefficients
- In seasonality, some SKUs use other SKUs as reference. The references are searched within the same subclass. Therefore when a subclass of the item that uses a reference SKU, those items must be updated.
- Run seasonality across the system. If this step is done first two step is redundant.
- Get a snapshot item file from ASO & compare it with parquet files & DB.
- Check training cleaning process. In 2021 it created duplication problems because DemandByProduct files are not updated. We resolved the problem in the code. But still it’s good to double check the output (particularly midseasons object)

# Errors during data transfer:

## Client failed to send early feed

Early feed won’t start. Therefore run `update_last_stock_date` task -that updates `academy_last_stock_date` variable in airflow- in the [post_process_DAG](https://airflow2.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?dag_id=academy_post_process) is manually or update `academy_last_stock_date` the value using the variables pane. If post process dag runs, no need to do that.

## Early data transfer failed

Early feed starts around 6-7 PM EST. Usually this happens because of a cluster error. The action depends on where the code is failed and the important part to consider is inventory table. Because at the end of the early feed [post_process_DAG](https://airflow2.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?dag_id=academy_post_process) is running and it truncates the inventory table.

### Failure in the data transfer DAG:

ost_process) is running and it truncates the inventory table.

### Failure in the data transfer DAG:

If this is the one that failed, then most likely the problem will not require much attention. Make sure the cluster is in a working state and clear the DAG.

### Failure in the rocket daily DAG:

If the task highlighted as blue (`supersede_inventory`) has run succesfully, then the solution is not too difficult. Even if the post process runs you can still continue running this DAG. But keep in mind that the cluster might be terminated. In that case recreate the cluster using [data transfer DAG](https://airflow2.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?dag_id=academy_data_transfer) and after the cluster is ready, run the tasks highlighted as red. After the master ip is succesfully set, clear the task/tasks that failed.

tasks highlighted as red. After the master ip is succesfully set, clear the task/tasks that failed.

If `supersede_inventory` is not completed yet, I’d recommend starting the early data transfer process from the beginning of the [data transfer DAG](https://airflow2.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?dag_id=academy_data_transfer). Keep in mind that `trigger_rocket_daily`  task will result in an error because the DAG has already been triggered. Therefore when you're in that step, you should go to [rocket daily DAG](https://airflow2.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?dag_id=academy_rocket_daily) clear tasks from the beginning.

.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?dag_id=academy_rocket_daily) clear tasks from the beginning.

After rocket daily is successful, you need to trigger the result transfer to the client via [data transfer DAG](https://airflow2.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?dag_id=academy_data_transfer). Because rocket daily DAG is to produce results, not to export results to Academy. Below screenshot shows the result transfer related part in the [data transfer DAG](https://airflow2.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?dag_id=academy_data_transfer). You need to clear both of them to be able to send results to the client.

_id=academy_data_transfer). You need to clear both of them to be able to send results to the client.

Note: If the failed task is `save_target`, then you won’t be able to clear it because you’ll get errors every time you try it. In that case you need to DELETE any records that exist in the `Academy.replenishment.ReorderPointsAndOrderUpToLevels` that belongs to the run id you’re running in [rocket daily DAG](https://airflow2.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?dag_id=academy_rocket_daily).
