## Final data transfer failed

Final data transfer starts around 10-11 PM EST. The steps explained in the early failure is valid for this one as well. Therefore please refer to the section above. Below you will see the additional information required in case of a failure.

### Failure in the data transfer DAG:

Same as early.

### Failure in the rocket daily DAG:

It’s even easier than early. You don’t need to restart data transfer from the beginning. Instead you can clear the upstream starting from `choose_cluster`.

## Final data transfer is late or failed but I can not solve the problem on time (before the 4 AM EST):

Final data transfer is late or failed but I can not solve the problem on time (before the 4 AM EST):

This part assumes that early transfer ran successfully. It means that we’ve already shared backup (prelim) orders with Academy team that will be used in case final is not on time. But there is one more file we need to provide: PreAllocation. Because PreAllocation is not shared in the early feed, we need to manually send PreAllocation files that has succesfully run in the early feed.

What we need to do is the following:

reAllocation files that has succesfully run in the early feed.

What we need to do is the following:

1. Find the run id of the early run. You can find the run id using the rendered as explained in the Early data transfer failed/Failure in the rocket daily DAG section above.
2. Find PreAllocation files that belong to the run id. Let’s say in the above example it is 11333. The files will be ready in s3://invent-academy-datastore/rocket/runs/11333/PreAllocation2/ even with the manifest files.Pre allocation run foldersPre allocation one dc example
3. Delete if there is any folder/file in s3://invent-academy/academy-prd/output/PreAllocation/
4. Copy/paste all of these folders to s3://invent-academy/academy-prd/output/PreAllocation/

# Order export failure

Please follow below procedure if we fail to export orders to the client (s3). To clarify it can not be used to fix the order export during the data feed. This procedure will be used if order export procedure is completely failed.

rt during the data feed. This procedure will be used if order export procedure is completely failed.

1. Let the customer know there is an issue with the order export.
2. Remove the values in the UI because the output is going to be inaccurate. (or at least block the UI using academy_ui_to_maps_transfer update_finalized_col_bq task.)
3. Run [Academy].[etl].[UpdateAllocationOrders] SP with the correct parameters. This will make sure that the orders approved previous day will appear in the backlog approved quantity column.
4. As the previous step is completed, re-run academy_maps_to_ui_transfer dag.
5. If there are any crossdock items to be exported (or items that don’t have a daily cycle), ask ASO team to update the review cycle temporarily for us to export orders next day.
6. For #5, if ASO team updates the review cycle, be aware of the fact that early run results will not include that change. Therefore the user would need to update the repl day info during the early feed.

nclude that change. Therefore the user would need to update the repl day info during the early feed.

# Updating the targets in production on short notice

This happens when there is an urgent request to remove or add some parameters just before the target export. In a normal case, if we have sufficient time before 1.00 PM CST -before we export the targets- (the sufficient time is around 4 hours so you should start around 09.00 AM CST), below are the steps we should follow:

Important WARNING before starting: if it’s later than 2.30 PM CST, DO NOT try to update the targets, you most likely WON’T be able to make it in time.

han 2.30 PM CST, DO NOT try to update the targets, you most likely WON’T be able to make it in time.

1. Disable parameter in the database (using disable scripts etc.) if there is a parameter
2. Run parameter_resolve task in academy_r_flow_dag to make sure the changes in #1 are effective in production code.
3. In this step there are two possibilities:If the DC replenishment has not ended yet which is the dc_post_process task in academy_r_flow_dag, then make sure dc_post_process task won’t run automatically. You can mark the task as failed to prevent running it, then trigger target_calculation task in  academy_r_flow_dag.If the DC replenishment has ended, then trigger target_calculation.
4. After the target_calculation is complete depending on the the status of dc_post_process in the Trigger dc_post_process and clear the rest of the process.Trigger dc_post_process, you don’t need to clear the rest of it.

s and clear the rest of the process.Trigger dc_post_process, you don’t need to clear the rest of it.

- Check previous day vs. today forecast difference. 'Diff' column is the rate of the forecasts. If Diff(the rate) is high (greater than 1) and the amount difference of the forecasts are also high. Check the comment and the other column to understand the reason. 1/0 columns show if a module is changed the forecast of the item. Output forecasts of the effective modules are also given in the table.

For example, the item's forecast in the first row is highly increased, and the reason is tagged as 'chainlevel'.

It was affected by the chainlevel module yesterday but not today. The chainlevel module checks the instock rate of the item. If the instock rate is low (filtering with some thresholds), the module updates the forecasts with ‘chainlevel forecasts’ calculated by the noob side weekly.

s), the module updates the forecasts with ‘chainlevel forecasts’ calculated by the noob side weekly.

Then check the [Report](https://tableau.inventanalytics.com/#/site/Academy/views/InventoryandForecastPlanning_2019SalesAdded/InventoryandForecastPlanning?:iid=1), which helps to understand if the change in the forecast is good or not. In the figure below, we can see that this item sold 13.3k units last year, so if it can get some inventory, it is most likely to sell this year.

Also, department 0144 contains gun-related items, and we know beforehand that gun-related items have vendor problems and inconsistent instock rates (mostly low). If there is inventory, these items will sell. That is why we do not take any action for this department most of the time. But it is always good to check to be sure.

2. Check if there is a failed task email.

One of the common fail emails:

good to check to be sure.

2. Check if there is a failed task email.

One of the common fail emails:

If the ‘daily data’ task fails in the noob daily dag, the reason is probably the previous day’s low sales. The log will have a line like this:

Check daily sales in the DB, the query:

select sum(Quantity),Date FROM academy.data.sales WHERE Date> '2022-01-10' group by Date

In this case, the same day’s sales were 490k last week, which is 69k this week. If there is a high sales difference, the system gives an error. It is ok to make success the task and continue the latter tasks.

- Example:

“simulation_report” task failed. “ERROR YarnScheduler: Lost executor 11 on ip-10-246-7-171.ec2.internal: Slave lost”

solution: 160 slot units increased to 208.

3. Check “ASO: Target Control Part-1 …” email

Firstly, check Department level target change to if there is an alarming situation. DolarChange_SS column shows percentage of the change in target.

o if there is an alarming situation. DolarChange_SS column shows percentage of the change in target.

## How can I update the seasonality curve in the system and make sure it affects the engine?

The seasonality curve update is a complicated process. Therefore, this document must be reviewed carefully before trying to change something in the system.

Every week on Mondays, when daily R flow ends, this process begins. You can see the order from [academy_ec2_controller DAG](https://airflow2.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?root=&dag_id=academy_ec2_controller&_csrf_token=IjNmYjQ3NDJjOTZkYmJiNjdkNGY0Yjk0M2FlNWE2ZjMzNmYwMWUxNjAi.YtHFsA.nw5MN26Tv5v0SdKDPzGPTeyG53w&base_date=2022-07-14T01%3A00%3A01Z&num_runs=25&execution_date=2022-07-10T01%3A00%3A00%2B00%3A00&arrange=LR). Below is an example DAG run on Monday. As you can see, when `wait_r_dag`, `wait_noob_daily_dag` and `wait_allocation_daily_dag` ends, seasonality process gets triggered.

ag`, `wait_noob_daily_dag` and `wait_allocation_daily_dag` ends, seasonality process gets triggered.

However, this process does not mean that the seasonality curves in the engine are updated. If the update of the seasonality curves becomes automated, this document should be updated. What this [seasonality DAG](https://airflow2.euwest1.prod.inventanalytics.com/graph?root=&dag_id=academy_ec2_controller&_csrf_token=IjNmYjQ3NDJjOTZkYmJiNjdkNGY0Yjk0M2FlNWE2ZjMzNmYwMWUxNjAi.YtHFsA.nw5MN26Tv5v0SdKDPzGPTeyG53w&base_date=2022-07-14T01%3A00%3A01Z&num_runs=25&execution_date=2022-07-10T01%3A00%3A00%2B00%3A00&arrange=LR) does is that it calculates the curves using the most recent information. But unless we update the tables in the database, the calculated curves will not be effective and the system will continue to use existing curves in the Database.

There are two types of tables related to seasonality in the database.

1. Production tables
2. Reporting tables

### Production Tables

ted to seasonality in the database.

These tables are the ones that actually affect the result of LLTD (Log Linear Timeseries Decomposition). They are being transferred to noob environment everyday, after the final data feed. You can check [this script](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/data-transfer/academy/-/blob/master/db_to_parquet.py)to see the transfer logics by searching term “*seasonality*”

SeasonalityTags.R:

- deaditem_run != '_Dead' icludes or excludes currently inactive items.
- shifts 2019,2018,2017 towards 2021 and excludes 2020.
- “product_sales_weekly[TotalDay <= (TotalDay_Lag0.75) | TotalDay <= (TotalDay_Lead0.75)  ,” excludes items with inconsistent totalday counts for consecutive.
- product_sales_weekly[, CriticalRate := ifelse(InStock*2 < TotalDay, 1, 0)] excludes item with low instock rate
- while (nrow1 > nrow2 & nrow(product_sales_weekly) > 0){ (line 179) finds the real beginning of items' life
- sales_weekly[Year==2021 & Week==6 & (DemandAdjusted2<DemandAdjusted_lag), shift_jump:=1]sales_weekly[Year==2021 & Week==5 & (DemandAdjusted2<DemandAdjusted_lead), shift_jump:=1] filter outs item with big jump on demand at the point of junction.
- sales_weekly[, ProductCountThreshold := ifelse(ProductCount > MaxProductCount/2,1, 0)] product count filter.
- The rest is commented in the script.

ProductCount > MaxProductCount/2,1, 0)] product count filter.
- The rest is commented in the script.

SeasonalityTags_method2.R:

- The same filters are applied, but items are not excluded. Instead, problematic days are detected and replaced with prophet predictions.

problematic_week_adj.R:

- Prophet prediction for problematic days

GroupSales.R: (GroupSales_method2.R similar)

- Groups the data for subclass, class, department.

Holidays.R: (Holidays_method2.R similar)

- Finds the special days and promotion days.

SeasonalityCalculation_v4.R:

- ‘scale’ is a hyperparameter that we can change. It affects the given importance (coefficient value) to special days. In the code, the best scale number is searched for a smooth seasonality curve at special days
- ‘main_calc’: first, depromo(sales_data, scale = scale) removes special days effects by finding special day coefficients, and reapplying the prophet formula.

emoves special days effects by finding special day coefficients, and reapplying the prophet formula.

original formula: fc = trend*(1+multiplicative terms ) = trend*(1 + seasonal + holiday + promo)

The formula assumed to be fc =  trend * seasonal * (1 + promo + holiday) to get approximate seasonality curve without special day effects by dividing the demand values to (1 + promo + holiday) . In the code below, holidays have promo coefficients in it.

```
overall_coef <- forecast_pd[, .(OverallCoefficient = pmax(1, 1 + holidays))]
```

```
temp[, DepromoSalesQuantity := DemandAdjusted/OverallCoefficient]
```

Then, in methods(depromo_sales) prophet and possible other models applied to newly found demand numbers.

Targetcalculation.R

1. Some Boolean objects at the beginning of the scripts are determined manually. What is the main reason of defining some Boolean objects in the script? And what do they mean?

(USER RUN ENHANCEMENT)

- The initial difference is the difference between a production run and user run. Production run is automated and updates the system on a daily basis. However, when a user runs the code (maybe the user wants to try to see the effect of some parameter change), by default the code prevents the user from updating the production system. The simplest example is the

*DBInsert*parameter. If it's TRUE then the result of the run gets uploaded to the database and affects the targets in production.

Inputdataload.R

1. “modelafterdata” object includes a column named “Percentage”. What does it mean?

(SIMILARITY)

R

1. “modelafterdata” object includes a column named “Percentage”. What does it mean?

(SIMILARITY)

- When the client introduces a new SKU (product) to the system they sometimes provide a model after SKU for the new item. It means that the new item is going to sell in a similar pattern(seasonality shape) to the model after SKU. The percentage column represents the level of the sale. For example, let's say the existing item sells 10 units a day and the percentage provided is %50. It means that the expected sales of the new item is 5 units a day.

2. inventory object includes columns named “NetIncomingStock” and “PDQInv”. What is the meaning of these columns?

(ON THE WAY-AVAİLABLE)

- In the simplest terms we can divide inventory into two parts.

1- On hand inventory: It's the physically available inventory to sell.

de inventory into two parts.

1- On hand inventory: It's the physically available inventory to sell.

2- Incoming inventory: The inventory is in the process of being sent to the store. However, it's not yet ready to sell because it might be at the warehouse or on the way to the store etc.

PDQ inventory is something client specific. We cannot see or calculate the incoming inventory for a specific set of items via ETL. Therefore, in these cases, the client sends us a list of PDQ inventory values to compensate those and we include those values to the incoming stock.

3. Which information does “presentation_level” object include?

(SAFETY STOCK?)

- Presentation level is the minimum inventory level that the client wants to maintain in the store for the item to present itself to the customer.

4. What does “active_pairs_skusumm” object refer?

(ACTIVE STORES FOR EACH SKU)

lf to the customer.

4. What does “active_pairs_skusumm” object refer?

(ACTIVE STORES FOR EACH SKU)

- Below is the query that generates this table. It shows the number of active (based on client's data -for academy it's ITEM_LOC.csv) stores for each SKU.

5. What does “sources” object mean?

(REPLENISHMENT SOURCE)

- It indicates the replenishment source of the sku-store.

W = Warehouse to store

C = Crossdock (Vendor to warehouse to store, but without placing the items to the shelves in the warehouse)

D = Direct to store (vendor to store)

6. What is the definition of “InputLeadTime_v00” column inside the “lead_time” object?

(RAW MATERIAL LEAD TIME)

- It's the raw lead time value we get from the client via ETL.

7. What is the meaning of “ASP” column of “asp” object and what is the difference between “unitMargin_v00” and “unitMargin_v01” columns included in the same object?

(AVERAGE SALES PRICE-AVERAGE UNIT RETAIL)

(HANDLE VALUES THAT DO NOT MAKE SENSE)

the same object?

(AVERAGE SALES PRICE-AVERAGE UNIT RETAIL)

(HANDLE VALUES THAT DO NOT MAKE SENSE)

- ASP = Average Sales Price, ASO calls it AUR (Average Unit Retail). The difference between unitMargin_v00 and v01 is to handle values that don't make sense (i.e. margin < 0 doesn't make sense)

8. What are the meanings of “FamilyId” and “Ismain” columns of “supersede” object?

(GROUPING OF SIMILAR PRODUCTS WHOSE CODE MIGHT BE CHANGED)

(ACTIVE = 1)

- When the code of an item (SKU, ProductCode) changes, we keep the track of it via Sub item-main item relation that is provided by the client data feed.  Basically, the item itself does not change, but the code of the item changes for some reason (ie. vendor changes the code). To handle that we link these items together and call it a family. Ismain column represents the code that is the newest (or active) when the value of the column is 1.

ue of the column is 1.

s “forecastdata” object include? what are the definitions of “sum_multip” column and “F_v99” column?

For an item every day has a seasonality multiplier (even if it doesn’t exist, default is 1) `sum_multip` is the sum of historical seasonality multipliers for the days that are included in the forecast (available days). `F_v99` is the forecast value to use in replenishment engine after some adjustment to the initial (raw) forecast value that comes from Noob(LLTD) engine.

If there are missing records, we should be finding that out in the emails. The subject of the email starts with *“RunParameters Log Target”*.

46- safetystockcalibrate object includes a quite number of columns. how do we use that object and what are the meaning of each column of the object?

number of columns. how do we use that object and what are the meaning of each column of the object?

`StoreRPL_StartingPoint`: Initial service level defined for the department in replenishment engine.

`StoreRPL_MaxPoint`: Maximum allowed service level defined for the department in replenishment engine.

`StoreRPL_MinPoint`: Minimum allowed service level defined for the department in replenishment engine.

If we have*“_opt”* after these column names, it refers to the same thing but optimal versions.

The other columns are the adjustments being made to the different clusters. For instance if Revenue_B = 0.1, it means that the service level will be increased by 0.1 for the items that are in “cluster B”.

targets in a store because there is a space constraint.

53. What is the main difference between running scripts in ECS and EC2?

Based on [AWS](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/): *Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) is a web service that provides secure, resizable compute capacity in the cloud.*

Cloud (Amazon EC2) is a web service that provides secure, resizable compute capacity in the cloud.*

Again based on [AWS](https://aws.amazon.com/ecs/): *Amazon Elastic Container Service (ECS) is a fully managed container orchestration service that helps you easily deploy, manage, and scale containerized applications.*

You can also check this link for [details](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/40575584/what-is-the-difference-between-amazon-ecs-and-amazon-ec2).

ps://stackoverflow.com/questions/40575584/what-is-the-difference-between-amazon-ecs-and-amazon-ec2).

In ASO, for R scripts, we have a dedicated (it has a certain IP) virtual machine (r5.2xlarge, Linux). It runs the R codes if we trigger it in that specific computer in the cloud. However, ECS uses container images. The virtual machines are not dedicated to use, every single code runs in a randomly selected remote machine and when the code ends the machine disappears. Technically, we can run as many as codes we want to run in parallel using ECS. Because each code runs on an independent virtual machine. But we can’t do that in EC2, because we have a limited memory (~64gb) and more codes we run in parallel, the higher probability to be out of memory.

54. what is the exact definition of aggregation level mentioned in[Seasonality Calculation]. It can be seen that aggregation_level table look like above. How do we understand the aggregation_level from the table?

aggregation_level table look like above. How do we understand the aggregation_level from the table?

You can take a look at [https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/academy-rscripts/-/blob/master/systemqualitycontrol/productagglevelsave.R](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/academy-rscripts/-/blob/master/systemqualitycontrol/productagglevelsave.R) . We use `Base` column as the aggregation_level. But when we export data to the client we are showing them `SAS_Base` column instead, because that’s how they use it. `BaseLevel` and `SAS_BaseLevel` show the level we are using. It’s either `ProductCode` or `StyleDiff`.

55.[Seasonality Calculation]it is said that ”we calculate the seasonality for the whole style-diff.”. so can we say that we obtain the same seasonality curve for all of the products having the same style_diff?

That’s correct.

tain the same seasonality curve for all of the products having the same style_diff?

That’s correct.

56. see[Seasonality Calculation]. Why  is the sales date aggregated weekly? Did we try to use aggregating sales data monthly or daily to obtain better seasonality curves?

We can try different things. I wouldn’t expect month level aggregation to work properly for the seasonality. Because month is too high level, you can’t even differentiate black friday from the rest of November for example. Daily version could work. It has some advantages and disadvantages. Advantages would be:

- Better promotion decoupling (because promotions are by day not week)
- Better special day coefficient (for example you could have even better differentiation for black friday)
- Differentiation of weekdays and weekends. Because weekends usually sell higher than weekdays

Disadvantages:

tiation of weekdays and weekends. Because weekends usually sell higher than weekdays

Disadvantages:

- Data is going to be 7x weekly data. Therefore data size is going to be greater.
- Daily data will be more volatile.
- The number of sales are going to be much smaller when we break it down to day level

Some additional comments:

- The differentiation of weekdays and weekends is not too difficult even if we use weekly aggregation. Because you can calculate a day effect using simple algorithms (i.e. sum total sales last year and get percentages by day)
- In Academy Sports, for the most cases we don’t really need day level forecasts (except the special days) because we sum the coverage period forecast in replenishment engine. And cover periods usually can be defined in weeks because most of the time it’s greater than 2 weeks.

nd cover periods usually can be defined in weeks because most of the time it’s greater than 2 weeks.

57. Can we give an example for each department - class - subclass - base definition for the Academy to get better understanding of which items or groups they include?

Not sure if I understand the question. Can you join `aggregation_level` and `products` tables using `ProductId` column? If that’s what you’re asking, you can filter certain items and add their data in this document.

58. Even though that subclass performs better in summer; seasonality curve of the subclass does not represent seasonality curve of an SKU.[Seasonality Calculation]. Why we do not use the better seasonality curve for the SKU’s if the subclass' seasonality curve performs better?

t use the better seasonality curve for the SKU’s if the subclass' seasonality curve performs better?

I think that statement is a little bit confusing and misdirects. We can update the statement as: total sales for the items within a subclass may not be the best representative for the SKU. Because SKU count may vary during the year. It should be taken into account when calculating the seasonality curve. There is no claim in that statement that subclass curve is better than SKU curve. To give an example:

*“Even though that subclass performs better in summer; seasonality curve of the subclass does not represent seasonality curve of an SKU.”* What this statement tries to say is even though when you look at the subclass sales you see a peak in Summer for example, it doesn’t necessarily mean that the SKU has a peak in Summer.

59. What do we mean by saying If the jointed week's DemandAdjusted difference is higher than 2 times[Seasonality Calculation]?

ing If the jointed week's DemandAdjusted difference is higher than 2 times[Seasonality Calculation]?

Because we are removing a year due to Covid in 2020, there is a year shift in the data. Therefore if there is a 2x ratio between 2020 week 5 and 2021 week 6 (because after we shift the years, 2020 week 5 becomes 2021 week 5), we are removing that item from the seasonality calculation because the baseline of the item could’ve changed significantly due to covid and we don’t want the algorithm to see that change as a seasonality.

60. do we compare the demand forecast results obtained from Method 1 and Method 2 for each group in terms of error values?

No, we’re not running Method 2 by default. But it’s a good idea. We should definitely try it on the same period. Because the evaluation periods are fundamentally different (Method 1 doesn’t have 2020)

same period. Because the evaluation periods are fundamentally different (Method 1 doesn’t have 2020)

61. Therefore if the starting week has less than week - standard deviation sales; we eliminate it.[Seasonality Calculation]. do we mean “mean(starting-week) < mean(week) - std.dev “?

That’s a good callout. I updated it as: *(mean - standard deviation) sales.*62. If an item sells less than 2 for a week; it will be susceptible to randomness highly.[Seasonality Calculation]. Shouldn't we check the other weekly sales of these items before eliminating them. there might be specific reason for selling less than 2 for that week.

Not really. If an item is selling less than 2 units per week (keep in mind that most of the items exist in more than 200 stores) the sales per store is ~0.01. It’s pretty much zero and it could be due to some other reason. It’s important to prevent outlier cases(it can be either too high or to low sales) as much as possible.

s important to prevent outlier cases(it can be either too high or to low sales) as much as possible.

63. If an item sells 65% of total sales in one month. How did we decide the 65% here? not sure that the percentage determined works for every item.

It’s an arbitrary number based on experience. These kinds of numbers are not great generally speaking. Because, if it’s 64.99% it’s not flagged, if 65.01% it’s flagged. But the high level idea is that if an item has ~65% of its sales within a single month historically, then the calculated seasonality curve could be misleading and could create potential problems in forecasting.

64. Also some tags gives us information about the sales pattern:[Seasonality Calculation]. how and where do we use these information gained from the tags?

It’s not being anywhere in the algorithms now. But sometimes it’s useful to know the pattern of the item before starting the analysis. Or it can be used in seasonality clustering when needed.

n of the item before starting the analysis. Or it can be used in seasonality clustering when needed.

65. In which R script we calculate “retail apply and using 4 - 4 - 5 schedule” arrangements to ensure every month has 4 weekend?

[SeasonalityTags.R](https://gitlab.com/invent-analytics/academy-rscripts/-/blob/master/Seasonality/SeasonalityTags.R)

66. standard deviation of month percentage[Seasonality Calculation], I did not get the definition of std of month percentage here.

The code calculates monthly percentage of sales within a year. i.e. let’s say an item’s seasonality curve is flat through the year and in every month the sales is approximately 1/12 = 12.5%. If you calculate the standard deviation across the month percentages it would be somewhere around zero. It’s a flag to determine whether the seasonality shape of the item is year round or seasonal. If the standard deviation is greater than 0.04 -based on the code- the item is flagged as seasonal.

If the standard deviation is greater than 0.04 -based on the code- the item is flagged as seasonal.

67. what do we mean by saying "we name the most prevalent sales patterns with 2 peaks."[Seasonality Calculation]

It’s a name we put when we flag the items. In the end an item would be shown something like this: “S 6 7” which means that the seasonality curve of the item is highly seasonal and it peaks around June & July timeframe.

- How the data is prepared?In TargetCalculation calculation code there are 2 scripts that saves data.datasaveforSimulationRun.R  & datasaveforSimulationRun_part2.R.Both of them runs on Saturday & Sunday.datasaveforSimulationRun_part2.R updates AcademyReporting.dbo.SimulationPairs for reporting codes on Saturday and Sunday. But the code that runs on Saturday is the effective one, because it's  being used in simulation_report.py. Because the data is converted to parquet file (AcademyReporting.dbo.SimulationPairs --> s3://invent-academy-datastore/simulation-scope/latest/) on Sunday morning in academy_emr_job_flow DAG. And it runs earlier than the datasaveforSimulationRun_part2.R on Sunday.  (You can see a visual below and review this task for details of what happens when it doesn’t run on Saturday  )For R codes there is an additional code that breaks data into departments simdatasave_withimage.R (which runs on academy_r_flow on Sundays, after TargetCalculation.R)

Space constrained targets are calculated in reorderpoint_calculation.R scripting by calling the function space_constrained_targets defined in the Functions_v00.R script. In this documentation, the mathematical idea behind the space constrained targets calculations is examined.

Space_constrained_targets <- function(SKUStoreTargets, spacecap_storeproduct, useOptimal=FALSE)

- We need pairs at that time(SKUStoreTargets) and spacecap_storeproduct table to run this function.

## Input tables

1) `StoreRPL_AdditionalLT_byH4.csv`

Includes `AdditionalLeadTime_ExcluseSOQCap` information for 4 classes only, as of April 13. Default value = 0.

2) `shipmentfreqtable.csv`

Contains shipment day information for stores. Default shipment day = Wednesday.

3) `REPL_ITEM_LOC`

Contains review cycle information.

If review cycle is 0, initial (unprocessed) `review time` is then assigned 7,

if review cycle is 1, initial (unprocessed) `review time` is then assigned 1,

otherwise (unprocessed) `review time` is assigned review cycle * 7. Default value for the initial (unprocessed) review time is 7.

4) <YYYY-mm-dd>_`SHIPPING_WINDOW.csv`

Contains shipping window information for suppliers. Includes Supplier_Site_Name, Supplier_Lead_Time, Ship_Window_Days details. “Shipping window” and “ShippingWindowDelay” are extracted from this file. Default value for `ShippingWindowDelay` is 0. If the source is “Warehouse”, then `ShippingWindowDelay` is 0.

value for `ShippingWindowDelay` is 0. If the source is “Warehouse”, then `ShippingWindowDelay` is 0.

5) Source information (`[Academy].[replenishment].[SupplySourcesByPair]`)

Table contains source information for product-store combinations (Warehouse → W, Crossdock → C, Supplier → D). Default value is `W` (Warehouse).

6) Warehouse Inbound Handling Days

If source is Crossdock (C), then `Warehouse Inbound Handling Days` is 1, otherwise it is zero.

7) `"ManualAdjustmentonResults.csv"`

Includes manual adjustments (`"CoverPeriodIncrease"` is one of them)

for reference purposes

> How do we calculate cover periods?

Cover period is basically the sum of lead time + review time. Below, we provide a breakdown of each item and explain how we get final cover times.

## Cover Period Calculation

A) Input Lead Times

Raw lead times are extracted from the following database table → “`Academy.replenishment.ShipmentDurationsByPair`". (Store | Product | LeadTime)

ing database table → “`Academy.replenishment.ShipmentDurationsByPair`". (Store | Product | LeadTime)

a) If a lead time of specific Product-Store combination is not present in this table, we take the average of the lead times for that Product-Source pair, and accept it as the initial lead time. Provided that mean lead time for that Product-Source cannot be calculated due to insufficient data again, initial lead time is assigned `7` if source is “Warehouse, `30` if source is other than “Warehouse”. Call the output of this step `"Input_LeadTime_v1"`.

b) If `Input_LeadTime_v1` is less than or equal to zero, it is assigned,

- 5, if source is "Warehouse",
- 14, otherwise.

Call the output of this step `"Input_LeadTime_v2"`.

- 5, if source is "Warehouse",
- 14, otherwise.

Call the output of this step `"Input_LeadTime_v2"`.

c) If the source is “Crossdock”, we add `ShippingWindowDelay` + `Warehouse Inbound Handling Days` on top of `Input_LeadTime_v2`, and if the source is “Supplier”, we only add `ShippingWindowDelay` on top of `Input_LeadTime_v2`, to get, say, `Input_LeadTime_v3.` This is our final `LeadTime` to be used in the following calculations.

B) Input Review Times

Raw review times are extracted from REPL-ITEM-LOC (article 3 of “[Input tables](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/academy/pages/3763830785/Cover+Period+Calculation#Input-tables)”).

a) We don’t allow raw review times to be lessthan,

- 1, if source is "Warehouse",
- 7, if source is "Crossdock",
- 7, if source is “Supplier” (direct to store).

b) We don’t allow raw review times to be greaterthan,

- 7, if source is "Warehouse",
- 28, if source is "Crossdock",
- 28, if source is “Supplier” (direct to store).

rce is "Warehouse",
- 28, if source is "Crossdock",
- 28, if source is “Supplier” (direct to store).

c) Finally, if source is “Warehouse” or “Crossdock”, we add `truck frequency` (*a hint: max truck freq. is 7 for Warehouse, 0 for Crossdock*) on top of review time, to get our final `ReviewTime`.

C) Getting the Final Cover Time

a) Initial (raw) cover time is equal to `LeadTime` + `ReviewTime` + `AdditionalLeadTime_ExcluseSOQCap`.

b) We don’t allow this value to be lessthan `15` for warehouse 001, `15` for warehouse 701, and `13` for warehouse 711.

c) We don’t allow this value to be greaterthan `35` when source is "Warehouse", and `56` otherwise.

d) Manual adjustments (article 7 of “[Input tables](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/academy/pages/3763830785/Cover+Period+Calculation#Input-tables)”) are applied at this step.

→ Resulting value is our `FinalCoverTime` for that Product-Store combination.

1. Clone related git repositories from GitHub (find Academy related repositories by searching “academy“ keyword under the “inventanalytics” organization). The ones in the below image are the ones that you will be dealing with daily. Make sure you have granted you “writer” permission on the repositories you will be working with.

1. Gather the following credentials:

- .aws
- sql_crdentials
- smtp_credentials

1. Move your credentials to specific folder.

For example (for sql):

- C:\Users\eren.kotar\Documents\sql_credentials

1. Config.json:

In customer-academy-rscripts repo, there is a .json file named “Config.json“. Every user has their credential paths for specific to them and their operating system. You can copy the one with the right OS and paste it carefully so it won’t change the format of others. Then, replace your paths that you moved in step above.

ully so it won’t change the format of others. Then, replace your paths that you moved in step above.

1. Adding user variable.

Right click [Thic PC] → [Advanced system setting] → [Environment Variables] → In User variables, click [New] → Write [academy-rscripts-path] to Variable name section and your customer-academy-rscripts repo path to the value, for example [C:\Users\eren.kotar\PROJECT\customer-academy-rscripts] → Click [OK]

Note: After setting the configuration right (gettin help from team members is recommended), some R script in the customer-academy-rscripts should be runned (example: *databasetablesizecheck.R*) to test if configuration is working and getting used to working style.

() Hi everyone,

The goal of this update is to move Confluence documentation pages to Academy UI Help Page (which uses wordpress). Similar approaches can be followed in other client projects.

There are several thoughts behind it:

Not all of our customers have confluence access (Academy could be one of few).

We can keep everything in the UI, it’d be much more compact for the client users.

It’ll cost less, because each additional Confluence user incurs additional cost. For example, in Academy there are possibly more than 50-60 users that use our UI page for reporting etc. But we cannot provide confluence access to all of them.

Academy Help Page can be accessed by clicking on the “Help” button that is located in the home menu of the UI. Basically, it directs the user to Academy Help Page.

The view of Academy Help Page can be seen below. It includes sub-pages that have Confluence documentation.

ew of Academy Help Page can be seen below. It includes sub-pages that have Confluence documentation.

Users can use the “Back” button that is located at the end of each documentation in the UI to turn back to the previous page.

`missingfrequencystores_before <- s3readRDS( object = file.path('Resolved_Parameters', 'missingfrequencystores.rds'), bucket = operations_bucket)`

[Mardi Gras - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mardi_Gras)

There are two actions/steps:

- Check DC replenishment results for Logo chairs (especially green & purple). Make sure the mardi gras stores are taken into account. This step should be completed in November/December timeframe. (3 months prior to the Mardi Gras, depending on when Mardi Gras is)
- Blackout mardi gras stores' mardi gras dates to prevent over ordering after the Mardi Gras. ([ASORPL-869] Mardi Gras Stores Blackout 2024 - JIRA (atlassian.net)

*Further improvement: Automate seasonality process for Mardi gras items.*

1. Solution quality:Year-round replenishment:Because the stores will not be replenished for a while, it means we are going to need to increase their review period. But because this affects all stores within a DC, this is not a small change. Increases in coverage period will result in higher targets and therefore higher orders. Higher order means we are going to need additional inventory at the DC. Therefore, before starting to increase the store targets, we have to increase DC inventory first. For crossdock items, we increased the coverage periods sooner because we don’t need to wait for DC inventory levels to increase.DC Replenishment:In order to be able to satisfy the order increase, first we added additional WOS to the DC so that we don’t get stock out at the DC when store targets increase. We started to increase DC targets by increasing the coverage period gradually for 4-5 weeks

ncrease. We started to increase DC targets by increasing the coverage period gradually for 4-5 weeks. Here’s the relevant task: [ASOCS-7898] TCDC Blackout - Increase replenishment prior / Stop replenishment during downtime - March 2024 - JIRA (atlassian.net)Year-round_replenishment (round 2):After the DC inventory is increased (i.e. the first extra orders received at the DC), we started to increase store targets. Basically we added additional coverage period to the stores that belong to TCDC. It was applied gradually too, 7 days, 14 days and lastly to increase the inventory further 21 days (21 days might have been a little too much but we agreed to do so with the client).!!!REMEMBER THAT THIS PROCESS STARTED MUCH EARLIER THAN APRIL (WE STARTED AROUND JANUARY)!!!

2. Technical Issues:There are no technically demanding changes until the actual downtime of the DC. There are several components of the engine that needs to be taken care of before the blackout (in this case 3/30).Seasonal Replenishment Dummy SKU generation:This script sends ASO sku-store combinations to be run on seasonal replenishment engine. They call it dummy parameters. It basically creates a REPL ITEM LOC record for each sku-store combination we send to them. We have to turn them off. Here’s the relevant git commit.SKU Store combination selection removal from all engines (except forecast)Relevant git commit. It updates the codes that run in the following DAG

all engines (except forecast)Relevant git commit. It updates the codes that run in the following DAG. preprocess DAGThe goal is to removes the sku-store selections of:Year-round replenishmentSeasonal replenishment(Allocation)DC replenishment.Additional manual removal from DC replenishment calc:Because ecom is also part of DC replenishment, even if we remove the sku-store scope, the system generates target for the ecom which is usually very small compared to original targets. But other than the quality, we shouldn’t be sending targets/orders for the blackout DC. Therefore we added following commit to the DC code itself.

1. we need to be able to run the CallConfig.R script without any error, we need to install the missing packages to our locale machine to ensure that.
2. we need to update the Config.json script. Basically, we add the new users’ information according to existing users and ensure you have the necessary user setup for both Windows and Linux.Config.json path: customer-academy-rscripts\Config.json
3. If running CallConfig.R results in a "Config.json not found" error, try these solutions:Set an environment variable:Right-click This PC → Advanced system settings → Environment Variables.Under User Variables, click New.Set the Variable Name to academy-rscripts-path and the Variable Value to the path of your academy-rscripts repository.Add the academy-rscripts folder under C://Users/your-username
4. Remember that latest Java should be installed to your local machine in order to run  CallConfig.R

To install the required R packages with their specified versions to the machine, follow these steps carefully. Note that the machine is running R version 3.6. Some libraries may not support installation through `this version`, so you might encounter errors when attempting to download the latest versions of certain packages. Please adhere to the package versions listed below. Go to the CallConfig.R start with making sure that you have successfully installed all libraries imported.

### Installation Instructions:

ng sure that you have successfully installed all libraries imported.

### Installation Instructions:

1. Using the Command Line: While the command install.packages("package-name", version = "version") is often used, it may not always work for older versions of packages. If you encounter issues, proceed to the next step.
2. Download the Correct Package Version:Visit CRAN and search for the package you need.Navigate to the "Archive" section for the package.Download the .tar.gz file corresponding to the required version.
3. Manual Installation:Open RStudio or your R environment.Go to Packages → Install → Install from Archive.Browse to the .tar.gz file you downloaded and select it for installation.Alternatively, you can use the following command in R to install from the local archive:

`install.packages("/path/to/package-name_version.tar.gz", repos = NULL, type = "source")`

- forecast: Version 8.23.0Download and install from the archive here.
- systemfonts: Version 1.1.0Download and install from the archive here.
- devtools: Version 2.4.3

1. Verify Installation: After installing each package, confirm it works by loading the library:library(package-name)

#### Target Calculation and Order Decision

1. Daily Target CalculationsTargets are calculated daily for each product-store combination.Compare today’s and yesterday’s targets:Detect and analyze increases or decreases.Replenishment decision:Should products be sent to stores based on targets?Factors:Order cost = Product cost + Inventory carrying cost.Safety stock and reorder point are calculated for each product-store combination.
2. Daily ASO OperationsLogs:Check RPLTarget_LOG for anomalies, especially after seeing peaks in reports.Target mail review:Daily target emails need documentation and monitoring.Data Checks:Download DetailedTargetResults.rds and investigate by product and store IDs.Analyze by grouping data (e.g., productId, storeId, department).
3. SKU CapsWeekly caps are provided for SKUs. Targets adjust based on caps:If target exceeds the cap, the cap is used as the new target.

#### Key Scripts and Processes

n caps:If target exceeds the cap, the cap is used as the new target.

#### Key Scripts and Processes

- Scripts:TargetControl.R (controls targets).Bulkflow algorithm (R scripts).targetCalculation.R (runs daily, saves logs to RPLTarget_LOG).
- Reports:AutoSeasonality Update Report: Runs quarterly. Review updates.Seasonality Calculation: Runs monthly (first week).Forecast and inventory planning are visualized in Tableau.

---

### Forecasting and Seasonality

#### Forecasting

nventory planning are visualized in Tableau.

---

### Forecasting and Seasonality

#### Forecasting

1. Models and Methods:Yearly replenishment uses:Prophet time-series model (additive and multiplicative models).Data cleaning is applied.Seasonal allocation uses:XGBoost and LightGBM models (data cleaning not applied here).
2. Forecast Challenges:Indicators of forecast issues:Instock vs. lost sales trends.Week-on-week sales differences.Seasonality misalignment or missing data.Products without 52-week data:Calculate seasonality at subclass or department level by aggregating data.Legacy systems handle seasonality with a threshold above +20 being problematic.

#### Seasonality

ta.Legacy systems handle seasonality with a threshold above +20 being problematic.

#### Seasonality

1. Calculation and Updates:Runs monthly (first week of the month).Includes adjacent weeks for special events/holidays.Binary columns like promoHigh, promoMed, and promoHoliday are used.Seasonal updates are quarterly (AutoSeasonalityUpdate).
2. Levels of Calculation:Hierarchy:Department → Class → Subclass → Product level.Errors typically occur at the product level.

---

### Replenishment and Allocation

1. Replenishment Process:Safety stock and reorder target point:Replenishment is triggered when stock falls below the reorder point.Costs:Inventory carrying costs and lost sales costs are simulated.
2. Allocation:Focus on seasonal allocation.Key Algorithms:Uses machine learning models like XGBoost and LightGBM.Truck limits and case backlogs affect decisions.

1. Monitor Target EmailsEmails arrive around 2–3 PM daily.
2. Check RPLTarget_LOG for PeaksReview the RPLTarget_LOG report after observing a peak.
3. Understand Target CalculationtargetCalculation.R runs daily, saving logs in the RPLTarget_LOG report.
4. Investigate Problematic DataDownload DetailedTargetResults.rds.Check specific ProductID, and compare today's and yesterday's data.
5. Group and Analyze DataGroup by ProductID, StoreID, and Department to identify issues.

We regularly receive parameter adjustment requests from the client. To handle these, we use an ad-hoc R script designed specifically for such requests.

This process involves two key components: a configuration file and an R script, both of which need to be run manually. However, the initial environment setup is a one-time process, eliminating the need to repeat these steps for future adjustments.

### Environment Setup

1. Locate the FilesThe required files are:FileReadPath_utku.jsonRCodetoInsertCaps_utku_new.RThese files can be found in the customer-academy-algo/OperationalScripts directory.
2. Understand the Configuration FileThe FileReadPath_utku.json file serves as the configuration file. It specifies the read and write paths for the script you want to run.

JSON File

Let's begin by reviewing and setting up the JSON configuration file before proceeding to the script execution.

| Dag | Time | Cadence | description |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| academy_data_transfer | 10pm - early1am - final | daily | # === DAG Overview ===# This DAG is designed for data transfer processes for the Academy. It performs ETL:# - Extracts raw data from S3 and other sources# - Transforms the data (e.g., updates eligibility, inventory tables, and applies calculations)# - Loads the processed data back into S3 or makes it available for reporting |
| academy_preprocess | before 1pm | daily - 30min | This DAG prepares the Academy's data for daily operations. It waits for previous data transfers to complete, updates key lists, and processes important database procedures. This ensures the system is ready for accurate forecasting, replenishment, and decision-making. |
| emr_job_flow |  | daily | This DAG is part of the Academy's data pipeline. It processes daily data by transferring, transforming, and preparing it for reporting and forecasting using AWS EMR clusters. |

| Version | Description |
| --- | --- |
| F_v00 | Initial base forecast value. |
| F_v99 | Adjusted forecast with BOP/WOS capping and corrections. |
| F_v100_P1 | Seasonally adjusted version of F_v99. |
| F_step_00 | Intermediate version after mapping F_v99_P1. |
| F_step_01 | Combines F_v99_P1 and F_v99_Max for refinement. |
| F_step_02 | Final forecast after all adjustments, including seasonality and caps. |
| F_step_02_Day_v00 | Converts F_step_02 into daily forecast values. |
| F_step_02_Day_woSeasonality_v00 | Removes seasonality from daily forecast values. |
| F_step_02_Day_v01 | Reintroduces seasonality for final daily forecast values. |
| FDay_v99 | Final daily forecast with seasonality adjustments. |
| FWeek_v99 | Converts FDay_v99 into weekly forecast values. |
| F_CP_v99 | Final forecast for the specified cover period. |

content:
| Version | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Target_v00 | Initial base target derived dynamically. |
| Target_v01 | Adjusted to meet the minimum DOS (Days of Supply) parameters. |
| Target_v02 | Capped for items with few available days to limit overestimation. |
| Target_v03 | Capped for high seasonality multipliers (e.g., excessive jumps in forecasts). |
| Target_v04 | Adjusted for overestimations caused by sales without inventory (stock-out correction). |
| Target_v05 | Capped conservatively when only one sales observation exists. |
| Target_v06 | Applied internal max target cap by store-product, if applicable. |
| Target_v07 | Adjusted for models effective after target evaluation. |
| Target_v08 | Dynamic cap applied, considering system-wide or special item constraints. |
| Target_v09 | Placeholder for future caps, currently mirroring v08. |
| Target_v10 | Adjusted for new stores based on initial order values. |
| Target_v11 | Increased for new stores using recent sales trends. |

content:
| Parameter Type | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Supersede Handling | Used to resolve relationships between main and sub-items (e.g., alternative SKUs or configurations) for consistency in calculations and constraints. |
| Freeze Targets | Defines fixed inventory levels for specific product-store combinations, preventing dynamic replenishment during the freeze period. |
| Minimum Targets | Specifies minimum inventory levels per product-store pair, ensuring a base stock to meet presentation or safety requirements. |
| Maximum Targets | Caps maximum inventory levels per product-store pair to prevent overstocking beyond safety or space constraints. |
| Holdout Quantities | Defines quantities reserved for specific purposes or scenarios, preventing their allocation to other uses. |
| Seasonal Replenishment Costs | Adjusts cost parameters dynamically for seasonal products to optimize replenishment strategies during high-demand periods. |

metadata.title: Understand The Academy working pipeline - summarized

content:
dynamically for seasonal products to optimize replenishment strategies during high-demand periods. |
| Stop Replenishment | Specifies stores or products excluded from replenishment, either temporarily or permanently, due to operational decisions or constraints. |
| Safety Stock Thresholds | Caps safety stock levels at product and store levels to align with operational constraints, ensuring balanced stock availability and service level. |
| Dynamic Cap Ignore | Excludes specific product-store pairs from dynamic cap calculations, enabling exceptions in replenishment limits. |
| Manual Adjustments | Allows manual intervention to override automated calculations for specific parameters, such as cover period, safety stock caps, or early push requirements. |
| Space Constraints (Max) | Sets maximum inventory levels based on space availability in stores for specific product groups, ensuring efficient use of store capacity. |

metadata.title: Understand The Academy working pipeline - summarized

content:
pace availability in stores for specific product groups, ensuring efficient use of store capacity. |
| Space Constraints (Min) | Sets minimum inventory levels based on space availability in stores for specific product groups, supporting presentation-level requirements. |
| Shipment Frequency | Determines the frequency of shipments to stores, influencing replenishment timing and quantities. |
| Forecast Error Adjustment | Adjusts forecast parameters based on historical errors to improve demand estimation accuracy. |
| Service Level Adjustment | Modifies service level parameters for stores based on predefined scenarios, enabling customized replenishment strategies. |
| Cross-Dock Vendor Minimums | Specifies vendor-specific minimum order quantities for cross-dock operations, ensuring compliance with supplier agreements. |
| Presentation-Level Min On Hand | Forces minimum on-hand quantities for certain product-store pairs to maintain display standards. |

metadata.title: Understand The Academy working pipeline - summarized

content:
| Forces minimum on-hand quantities for certain product-store pairs to maintain display standards. |
| DC Truck Rounding | Implements rounding rules for DC (Distribution Center) shipments, ensuring adherence to truck load constraints and efficient ordering. |
| Early Push Adjustments | Adjusts inventory replenishment schedules to push stock early for specific product groups or stores during seasonal or demand spikes. |
| New Store Priorities | Assigns priority levels and replenishment parameters for new stores based on their unique requirements and startup timelines. |
| High-Priority SKU-Stores | Identifies high-priority product-store pairs for pre-allocation or prioritization in replenishment decisions. |

# DAG Details

## academy_preprocess

### [wait_emr_job_flow]

This one used to fail in 12 hours. It used to take ~8 hours to run the whole emr_job_flow DAG. But recently the run times have increased therefore it fails after 12 hours. We’ve recently increased it to 15 hours. It’s not urgent, just gives the team a heads up that the process took longer than expected. There could be other problems in the noob daily dag or emr_job_flow dag. But if there aren’t any other failures, this by itself is not a problem.

## academy_controller_final

### [file_sensor]

any other failures, this by itself is not a problem.

## academy_controller_final

### [file_sensor]

Final feed expects 5 different folders to be received (at `s3://invent-academy/academy-prd/input/final`). It won’t start if all folders are not ready. If this happens, send an email to Academy team. [Emergency Playbooks]

### [early_data_transfer_check]

Check if early data feed failed or not. Usually, if early is failed, we will have errors in other processes before this one.

### [post_process_check]

Uf there are errors in the post process DAG this task will fail. It’s not very common. If that occurs, reach out to project team.

## academy_controller_early

### [file_sensor]

Final feed expects 3 different folders to be received (at `s3://invent-academy/academy-prd/input/early`). It won’t start if all folders are not ready. If this happens, send an email to Academy team. [Emergency Playbooks]

### [wait_early_runs]

ready. If this happens, send an email to Academy team. [Emergency Playbooks]

### [wait_early_runs]

Reach out to project team. If this happens probably it’s not going to be an easy fix.

## academy_data_transfer

### ANY DT TASK

Please refer to the document below if you are seeing an error in the data transfer.  There could be two different scenarios here: failure in early or final feed. If it failed:

- In the early feed: Emergency Procedures
- In the final feed: Emergency Procedures (as of 1/2/2025, same procedure)

## academy_rocket_daily

### ANY ROCKET TASK

Please refer to the document below if you are seeing an error in the rocket daily.  There could be multiple scenarios here:

- In the early feed: Emergency Procedures
- In the final feed: Emergency Procedures

## academy_noob_daily

### [daily_data]

rgency Procedures
- In the final feed: Emergency Procedures

## academy_noob_daily

### [daily_data]

It usually occurs when there is a significant difference in sales/inventory compared to previous week same day. Examples are black friday, thanksgiving etc. Check the log in airflow. If you are seeing something like this:

```text
ERROR IO control failed Some control columns are out of bounds. Please check the output dataframe.
```

reach out to project team, but the most likely solution is to mark the task as `SUCCESS` and let the system continue.

Another potential issue here is memory issues. Sometimes, when there is a memory issue, cluster shuts itself down. In that case first log will be a memory issue (Lost executor etc.) and the second log will be a timeout which is not really a timeout and you need to clear the tasks `create_cluster` and `get_master_private_ip` in [emr_job_flow DAG](https://academy.prod.airflow.inventanalytics.com/dags/academy_emr_job_flow/graph)

[emr_job_flow DAG](https://academy.prod.airflow.inventanalytics.com/dags/academy_emr_job_flow/graph)

### [daily_data_dc]

It usually occurs when there is a significant difference in sales/inventory compared to previous week same day. Examples are black friday, thanksgiving etc. Check the log in airflow. If you are seeing something like this:

```text
ERROR IO control failed Some control columns are out of bounds. Please check the output dataframe.
```

mark the task as `SUCCESS` and let the system continue.

### [xgb_model_save]

If there is a failure here, the solution will be in the allocation weekly dag [size_breakdown](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/academy/pages/4773085186/Potential+Failures+Actions#%5Bsize_breakdown%5D.1) on (most likely on Mondays or Tuesdays) and allocation daily dag [size_breakdown](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/academy/pages/4773085186/Potential+Failures+Actions#%5Bsize_breakdown%5D) (on Wednesdays).

### [forecast_coefficients]

85186/Potential+Failures+Actions#%5Bsize_breakdown%5D) (on Wednesdays).

### [forecast_coefficients]

Most likely memory errors, clear the task 2 times if it still doesn’t run, reach out to project team.

Sometimes, when there is a memory issue, cluster shuts itself down. In that case first log will be a memory issue (Lost executor etc.) and the second log will be a timeout which is not really a timeout and you need to clear the tasks `create_cluster` and `get_master_private_ip` in [emr_job_flow DAG](https://academy.prod.airflow.inventanalytics.com/dags/academy_emr_job_flow/graph)

## academy_allocation_weekly

### [aggregate_train_and_predict]

This task has a special need. It’s very reare that it fails by itself. This code usually starts running on Monday. But almost 80% of the time it hangs. There is a specific procedure. To be written

If the aggregate_train_and_predict task is in the running status for more than 2 hours, follow below steps.

aggregate_train_and_predict task is in the running status for more than 2 hours, follow below steps.

- Compare the model_output_cache folder and model_output folder located in the s3/invent-academy-datastore/output/allocation directory.
- Check the number of items in both folders. They must contain the exact same number of subfolders.
- If the numbers do not match, check the latest update time of the model_output_cache folder.
- If the latest update time of the model_output_cache folder is more than 30 minutes old, it indicates that the task is hanging.
- If these conditions are met, clear the aggregate_train_and_predict task and mark it as failed as soon as possible.
- Recheck the folders. If the number of items in both folders matches, mark the aggregate_train_and_predict task as successful. This will trigger the downstream tasks to start running automatically.

### [size_breakdown]

Most likely a memory issue. Try to clear 2 times, if it doesn’t work reach out to project team.

Note: Sometimes after a memory issue, cluster shuts itself down. In that case first log will be a memory issue (Lost executor etc.) and the second log will be a timeout which is not really a timeout and you need to clear the tasks `create_cluster_2` & `get_master_ip_2` before clearing `size_breakdown`.

### [common_issues] (Handling Long-Running Tasks)

If you notice that any of tasks is running for more than 5-6 hours, it indicates that the code may be hanging. Follow these steps to resolve the issue:

than 5-6 hours, it indicates that the code may be hanging. Follow these steps to resolve the issue:

1. Close the Cluster:Terminate the existing academy_allocation_weekly cluster on Amazon.
2. Clear Specific Tasks:Clear the create_cluster and get_master_ip tasks in the Dag to create a new cluster.Clear the failed task while ensuring Upstream is selected.
3. Monitor the Task Status:Continuously monitor the status of the failed task after restarting the cluster.If the issue persists, reach out to the project team for further assistance.

## academy_maps_to_ui_transfer

### [update_ui_allocation_result]

Usually memory related and rerunning will make it work. Sometimes, when there is a memory issue, cluster shuts itself down. In that case first log will be a memory issue (Lost executor etc.) and the second log will be a timeout which is not really a timeout and you need to clear the tasks `create_cluster`, `install_odbc`, `wait_install_odbc` and `get_master_ip`. (If that’s the case simplest way is to clear `update_ui_allocation_result` task by clearing upstream as well.)

### [wait_emr_job_flow]

### [target_calculation]

It’s very rare for this code to fail on a day other than Monday. On Mondays however, it could conflict with [simulation_reporting](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/academy/pages/4773085186/Potential+Failures+Actions#%5Bsimulation_reporting%5D). If that happens, there are few steps we need to follow:

1. Mark target_calculation as Failed (if it already failed, do not clear).
2. simulation_reporting is more time sensitive, therefore make sure it’s running.
3. Mark lost_sales_to_DB as Failed.
4. Wait all the tasks to be complete until lost_sales_to_DB (it would take ~2hours)
5. When export_detailed_invforecastdata is completed, clear target_calculation and its downstream tasks.

We have a report in tableau called KPI Report:

This report provides some KPIs on a weekly basis, down to the department level, including sales units and dollars, inventory, instocks, lost sales, and total cost of sales. The underlying table for that report is academyReporting.tableau.KPI_Report_current, which is updated each week by the script [KPI_Report_Current.R](https://github.com/inventanalytics/customer-academy-rscripts/blob/master/reportingcodes/KPI_Report_Current.R).

thub.com/inventanalytics/customer-academy-rscripts/blob/master/reportingcodes/KPI_Report_Current.R).

A newer version of the product-level script, called [KPI_Report_ProductLevel_v2.R](https://invent.atlassian.net/wiki/pages/resumedraft.action?draftId=4773085303&draftShareId=d94c5c5d-7438-40d1-bd31-a37e4471992b), was subsequently created that generates output to the subclass level and also has a few adjustments to the history-gathering process. This is the recommended version to use for any future ad hoc KPI reporting. Note, however, that there is one remaining problem with this script; it reads in the Sunday target logs for each history week to determine which items were active for seasonal replenishment vs. year-round replenishment, but those logs are not reliable, because of production problems that resulted in the seasonal replenishment results not getting included. To fix this, that code should look elsewhere to determine what was on seasonal replenishment in historical weeks. The best approach needs to be researched and implemented

seasonal replenishment in historical weeks. The best approach needs to be researched and implemented. This problem also affects the original script (KPI_Report_Current.R) if used to go back and reconstruct the history for weeks earlier than September of 2024.

This guide outlines how the Inventory & Forecast Report is created using `simulationreporting.R`, database tables, and S3 RDS files. It explains key data sources, processing steps, and how forecasts and metrics are aligned to generate actionable insights.

1. Simulation Data: Metrics are primarily generated from simulation data stored in objects like aggregated and dept_agg.

After the forecast date, `Sls Ttl U` is indirectly derived from:

- Forecast data (Unit_Forecast) from simulations,
- Base-level forecasts (SAS_Sls_Ttl_U) from sas_info,
- Proportional SKU allocation logic (InventSASForecastSKUShare).

While `metrics` originates from simulations, the `sas_info.rds` file provides aggregated sales data at the SAS base level for certain higher-level calculations

InventSASForecastSKUShare := Forecast_SalesMerge / InventTotalWeekForecastSAS_WeekFC := SAS_Sls_Ttl_U * InventSASForecastSKUShare

## Background:

On a daily basis, there are auto-generated e-mails for Academy Sports & Outdoors that focus on different areas of their solutions.    The general theme of these e-mails are:

- Informative e-mails that summarize results of daily processes
- Confirmation of successful completion or failure of back-end process

## Distribution:

The e-mails are sent to different groups of individuals depending on content.  These include:

- academy-service.invent.ai  (invent.ai team responsible for ASO)
- teaminvent@academy.com  (hub team at Academy)
- UC4OPS@academy.com, abidatawatch@academy.com, enterpriseoperations@academy.com, intelgrp@academy.com, FulOptSysSupport@academy.com

## Rationale

The reason why we review these e-mails is to prevent potential incorrect data to be sent to Academy on a daily basis.   This is a good page to review as additional background:  [Notes on Onboarding]

## Actions Required

Below are the steps required to be taken by e-mail subject line:

n Onboarding]

## Actions Required

Below are the steps required to be taken by e-mail subject line:

### “ASO:  Target Control Part 1  and 2 YYYY-MM-DD” E-mails

These e-mails are sent DAILY to the [academy-service@invent.ai](mailto:academy-service@invent.ai) e-mail address (a sample header of the e-mail is included below).

The main action required for this e-mail is to review that the Unit Change and Dollar Change (or the last 4 columns in the first table in the body of the e-mail) is within -1% to 1% change.  If it is higher, it should be investigated.

In the case that the change is higher than the usual range of -1% to 1%for either units and/or dollars, review the remaining Department Level Target Change.  In the table, look for departments that may be causing the number to be a lot higher or a lot lower than expected and use the Part 2 e-mail to explore the reasons why.

o be a lot higher or a lot lower than expected and use the Part 2 e-mail to explore the reasons why.

If the higher or lower than normal change cannot be explained by the table summaries included in Part 1 and Part 2 e-mails, the issue should be escalated to the Academy data science team.

If done before 12PM on the day, the team is able to implement corrective actions so that errors in the data are not sent to Academy at the end of the business day.

### “ASO:  Target Control Part 3 YYYY-MM-DD” E-mails

These e-mails are sent DAILY to the [academy-service@invent.ai](mailto:academy-service@invent.ai) e-mail address (a sample header of the e-mail is included below).

The main action required for this e-mail is to review new items added to Academy’s replenishment SKU count to look for any unexpected department increases.

## Summary

The current inventory troubleshooting report helps replenishment analysts (RAs) and CMT partners understand order quantities, especially when orders are higher than expected. The ASO highlighted the need to simplify data from the original 49 columns to a more digestible 25, focusing on key components like SOQ and forecasts to explain order rationale and identify areas for adjustment.

The report is built using data pulled from two reports:

1. Store RPL Result Summary (Reports > Diagnostic > Diagnostics Store RPL > Store RPL Result Summary)
2. DC RPL Result Summary (Reports > Diagnostic > Diagnostics DC RPL > DC RPL Result Summary)

## Store & DC Replenishment Dashboard

metadata.title: Weekly: Store and DC Replenishment Dashboard WIP

content:
ts > Diagnostic > Diagnostics DC RPL > DC RPL Result Summary)

## Store & DC Replenishment Dashboard

The report is built off of the exported data from the two reports listed above.  The day after orders are generated is the best day to run these reports.  For example, on Monday for orders that are generated on Sunday.

From the hub team’s perspective, the focus is on quantityand visibility.The top questions they get from their team are:

- Why is the system ordering this quantity that is more than I thought it would be? (rather than why is it not ordering enough?)

The report aims to provide transparency and visibility into what is causing orders or transfers to generate, addressing the disconnect between planner estimates and the system’s logic.  There is also a lack of visibility beyond the chain level in planning, leading to discrepancies when inventory is concentrated in one DC.

Frequency

metadata.title: Weekly: Store and DC Replenishment Dashboard WIP

content:
ain level in planning, leading to discrepancies when inventory is concentrated in one DC.

Frequency

This report is not pulled on a regular weekly basis as a general summary for the entire team, but rather as a reaction to specific questions or "call-outs" from teams about high orders. While reports are saved for backward visibility, this specific template is a troubleshooting tool, though the aim is to instill a process for RAs to run it weekly after orders are placed.

While warehouse transfers are auto-approved, almost all other purchase orders sent to suppliers require manual review (semi-auto), with a 99% review rate.

Store Level vs. DC Level Data

The report primarily focuses on store-level data, as orders at the DC are understood to originate from the store side, and the current UI scope is at the store REPL level. There is a DC summary section in the report to provide a higher-level view of DC orders.

Key Focus Areas in the Report

metadata.title: Weekly: Store and DC Replenishment Dashboard WIP

content:
ry section in the report to provide a higher-level view of DC orders.

Key Focus Areas in the Report

The team focuses on several key data points in the report, including door count, average presentation level, cover period, and cover period forecast. Door count is important for comparing Invent's view against sell forecasts to ensure alignment. Average presentation level helps identify if pre-stocks are too high, suggesting adjustments to reduce orders.

SOQ - Suggested Order Quantity

The components of the SOQ (System Order Quantity) are considered the most important columns in the report, crucial for explaining why specific quantities are being ordered.

Forecast and Inventory Components

metadata.title: Weekly: Store and DC Replenishment Dashboard WIP

content:
crucial for explaining why specific quantities are being ordered.

Forecast and Inventory Components

The report includes last four weeks of actual sales versus future weekly forecasts, which are discussed in tandem with in-stock levels to explain order rationale. It also details inventory components such as active inventory, net inventory, and excess inventory, indicating where excess stock is located, often at granular levels.

Analysis Granularity

Analysis typically starts based on the call-out, often at a class or department level, but the team emphasizes drilling down to the item level. They advise sorting by SOQ (highest to largest) to identify the most significant ordering items and focus on addressing them at the SKU level rather than broadly applying changes at the class or department level.

Vendors

metadata.title: Weekly: Store and DC Replenishment Dashboard WIP

content:
hem at the SKU level rather than broadly applying changes at the class or department level.

Vendors

The team does not typically focus on vendors for analysis in this report, as issues are usually item-specific rather than vendor-discriminatory. The internal hierarchy, where buyers manage specific brands, often leads to organic analysis of vendor-related overstocking if it occurs.

Replenishment Analysts

There's a common misconception that high orders are solely due to high forecasts; however, the report often reveals that other factors like presentation stock or similar are the primary drivers. RAs do not have direct access to adjust forecasts but can control parameters, necessitating escalation to the team for target adjustments.

### SOQ Analysis Sub-Report

metadata.title: Weekly: Store and DC Replenishment Dashboard WIP

content:
arameters, necessitating escalation to the team for target adjustments.

### SOQ Analysis Sub-Report

This analysis groups SKU-store combinations based on order quantity, explaining the rationale (e.g., low in-stock, low weeks of supply) and identifying areas for potential SOM or pre-stock reductions. This view helps build trust by deconstructing large numbers into actionable insights, showing where inventory is truly needed versus where it is overstocked.

## Store RPL Result Summary

Path:  Reports > Diagnostic > Diagnostics Store RPL > Store RPL Result Summary

The current report has two levels - with top level summary as a result summary and the second level breaking out the items listed in level 1 in more detail.

Suggestion:   A reduction in reporting levels for from three to two: one higher-level hierarchy and one SKU-level hierarchy. The existing "level two" report is rarely used, proposing that the summary dashboard serve as the higher level, with underlying exportable data constituting the SKU-level summary.

## Hierarchy Used in Reporting

Reporting and filters include a product hierarchy, however, there have been some inconsistency in how the hierarchy is presented across the platform. A consistent hierarchy and order of fields across all reports would improve user experience.

In other areas of the platform and reports, store on hand and net store inventory are not always consistently in the same order.

## Rounding Numbers

Rounding numbers happens in the platform and in reports, however, important that there is consistency.  There are certain numbers that should be rounded to one, two or three decimal places and outlined in the below table.

ult Summary: Columns

Path:  Reports > Diagnostic > Diagnostics Store RPL > Store RPL Result Summary

While most of the columns of the report are being used by the Academy team, there are a number that they find are not adding value to their daily or weekly reporting specifically for the Store RPL Result Summary report.

Removing Columns

When Academy team downloads the report, they have 49 columns that they reduce significantly.    For example, the dollar breakdown of SOQ is not helpful as the team primarily focuses on units rather than dollars.  Another field - input lead time is not necessary as cover period is sufficient.  Row # is also not needed, but is OK if it can not be removed.

Adjusting Columns

metadata.title: Reporting and UI Observations and Feedback

content:
iod is sufficient.  Row # is also not needed, but is OK if it can not be removed.

Adjusting Columns

Additionally, there are columns that can be adjusted or added to provide more consistency and an improved user experience that will assist in engaging the replenishment team.    For example, Target weeks of supply and store on hand weeks of supply are currently calculated manually and would be beneficial to have readily available for reference.

Average sales columns is another that can be adjusted as  six weeks is a more commonly used and relevant timeframe for trend analysis by Academy planners.

Current weeks of supply seems an inaccurate description considering what it is calculating is “net inventory weeks of supply”.

Cover periodis inconsistently displayed in weeks at the high level and days at the lower level, and should be consistently days across both levels.

metadata.title: Reporting and UI Observations and Feedback

content:
s at the high level and days at the lower level, and should be consistently days across both levels.

In-stockmetric on the report usually does not align with actual on hand figures or store out of stock data.   A clarification on how "last week in stock" is calculated is needed.  There is a preference for the "in stock" metric to reflect actual on-hands at the time the report is run, possibly by simply naming it "in stock".

The miscellaneous suggested order quantity (SOQ MISC) needs a clearer definition or breakdown.  It is currently presumed to relate to SOM or parameters.

Forecasting safety stocks do not always equal the target, noting that factors beyond simple formulas, such as margin and service levels, influence system calculations.   That is, "Cover SS" column should equal *Cover Period Forecast* + *Safety Stock* but does not currently.

## Other Reports Feedback

metadata.title: Reporting and UI Observations and Feedback

content:
ld equal *Cover Period Forecast* + *Safety Stock* but does not currently.

File Manager

A significant cleanup is needed in the file manager due to an excessive number of reports, some dating back to January 2024, which they believe might contribute to slowdowns, especially on Mondays. They expressed a willingness to help identify which reports are essential, suggesting that data going back seven to eight weeks is likely sufficient for their needs.
